Use image_upright. --> | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> Charles J. Brotman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1927|12|30}} | birth_place = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = Announcing the US presidential inaugurations from Eisenhower to Obama | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }}
'''Charles J. "Charlie" Brotman''' (born December 30, 1927<ref name="tuscaloosa">{{cite news | last = White | first = Joseph | title = Brotman's Tales: A basement full of Washington's baseball past | newspaper = Tuscaloosa News | location = Tuscaloosa AL | date = 2005-01-22 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=20050122&id=sW40AAAAIBAJ&sjid=kaYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4859,2299293 | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref><ref name="washingtonian1">{{cite news | last = Jaffe | first = Harry | title = Brotman's Birthday Celebrated by Many | newspaper = Washingtonian | location = Washington DC | date = 2008-01-24 | url = http://www.washingtonian.com/blogs/capitalcomment/scene/brotmans-birthday-celebrated-by-many.php | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref>) is an [[United States|American]] [[public relations]] specialist and [[public address]] [[announcer]], known for his presentation of [[United States presidential inauguration|U.S. presidential inaugural]] parades of 11 presidents from [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] to [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/08/politics/donald-trump-charles-brotman-inauguration-announcer/index.html|title=Trump drops inauguration announcer who's done them all since Eisenhower|last=CNN|first=Eric Bradner|website=CNN|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Brotman, the son of Russian-Jewish immigrants, grew up in [[Northeast, Washington, D.C.|Northeast]] Washington, DC, graduated from [[McKinley Technology High School]] and studied at the [[University of Maryland]].<ref name="washingtonian1" /> He served in the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] from 1946 to 1948,<ref name="washingtonian2">{{cite news | last = Jaffe | first = Harry | title = Charlie Brotman to Announce His 15th Inaugural Parade Monday | newspaper = Washingtonian | location = Washington DC | date = 2013-01-18 | url = http://www.washingtonian.com/blogs/capitalcomment/inauguration-2013/charlie-brotman-to-announce-his-15th-inaugural-parade-monday.php | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref> then attended the National Academy of Broadcasting. Brotman was one of the academy's students selected by the organizers of [[Harry S. Truman]]'s [[Second inauguration of Harry S. Truman|inauguration]] in 1949 to broadcast the first-ever televised inaugural ceremony.<ref name="washingtonian1" /><ref name="wusa9">{{cite news | last = Leshan | first = Bruce | title = Charlie Brotman Has Been The Voice Of the Inaugural Parade Since 1949 | newspaper = WUSA-TV 9 | location = Washington DC | date = 2013-01-20 | url = http://www.wusa9.com/news/article/238922/158/Meet-The-Voice-Behind-The-Inaugural-Parade- | accessdate = 2013-01-21 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130217015329/http://www.wusa9.com/news/article/238922/158/Meet-The-Voice-Behind-The-Inaugural-Parade- | archivedate = 2013-02-17 | df = }}</ref>
Following his graduation from the academy, Brotman worked as a disc jockey and sports announcer in [[Orlando, Florida]].<ref name="washpost" /><ref name="tablet" /> A 1956 meeting with Senators' owner [[Calvin Griffith]] led to him returning to his hometown of Washington to take the Senators announcing assignment. He later became the team's promotions director as well.<ref name="tuscaloosa" />
In the 1960s, Brotman started his own public relations firm, Brotman|Winter|Fried, specializing in sports promotions.<ref name="bwf">{{cite web | title = Bio: Charlie Brotman, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board | publisher = Brotman|Winter|Fried | url = http://aboutbwf.com/content/charlie-brotman | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref> (His firm was acquired by Sage Communications in 2011.<ref name="sage" />) He continued to announce on Opening Day for the Senators each year until the team moved to [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas]] following the 1971 season. When the [[Washington Nationals]] relocated to the city in 2005, Brotman returned to his Opening Day duties.<ref name="nationals">{{cite web | last = Seidel | first = Jeff | title = Brotman is back behind the microphone | publisher = Washington Nationals | date = 2005-04-01 | url = http://washington.nationals.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20050401&content_id=993435&vkey=news_was&fext=.jsp&c_id=was | accessdate = 2013-01-21 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130201124827/http://washington.nationals.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20050401&content_id=993435&vkey=news_was&c_id=was&fext=.jsp | archivedate = 2013-02-01 | df = }}</ref>
Brotman joined [http://linksp.com/ LINK Strategic Partners], a strategic communications and stakeholder engagement firm based in Washington, DC, as a [http://reingoldlink.com/article/Brotman-Press-Release-02-09-15.html senior advisor] in 2015. He advises the firm on its hyperlocal engagement work in DC and around the country.
Brotman has been inducted into 11 different Halls of Fame during his more than 50 years in public relations and announcing, including the Washington Hall of Fame, the Jewish Sports Hall of Fame, Jock’s Hall of Fame, the Public Relations Society of America Hall of Fame, the Advertising Club of Washington Hall of Fame, the Greater Washington Fastpitch Softball Hall of Fame. His most recent induction took place in 2014 at the John F. Kennedy Center for Performing Arts for the Washington Tennis and Education Foundation Hall of Fame.<ref>[http://www.citiopentennis.com/hall_of_fame/ WTEF Hall of Fame.] Citi Open. Retrieved 2015-02-09.</ref>
==As an inauguration announcer==
Prior to taking on his inaugural duties, Brotman had been the stadium announcer at [[Griffith Stadium]], home of the [[History of the Washington Senators|Washington Senators]] baseball team.<ref name="pic">{{cite web | last = Somanader | first = Tanya | title = Meet Charlie Brotman, the voice of the inaugural parade | publisher = The Presidential Inauguration Committee 2013 | date = 2013-01-16 | url = http://www.2013pic.org/blog/post/meet-charlie-brotman-the-voice-of-the-inaugural-parade | accessdate = 2013-01-21 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130223060010/http://www.2013pic.org/blog/post/meet-charlie-brotman-the-voice-of-the-inaugural-parade | archivedate = 2013-02-23 | df = }}</ref> Brotman noted that on [[Opening Day]] 1956, Eisenhower was at the ballpark to throw out the [[ceremonial first pitch]]. Later that year, a White House staffer called Brotman and said Eisenhower was impressed with his work, and he wanted Brotman for the inauguration.<ref name="tablet">{{cite news | last = Hoffman | first = Allison | title = Inaugural Parade’s Jewish Voice | newspaper = Tablet | date = 2013-01-18 | url = http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/121887/inaugural-parades-jewish-voice | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref>
The staffer asked Brotman, "Will you charge a fee? Because our parade budget is very minimal." Brotman responded, "No, as a matter of fact, to be honest, I'd pay you for the honor."<ref name="time">{{cite news | last = Stephey | first = M.J. | title = Q&A: Inaugural Parade Announcer | newspaper = Time | date = 2009-01-20 | url = http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1872598,00.html | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref>
Brotman was behind the microphone for every inaugural parade in [[Washington, DC]], since 1957, when [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] was sworn in for his second term.<ref name="washpost">{{cite news | last = Kunkle | first = Fredrick | title = Inaugural parade’s announcer knows how to call ‘em as voice of former Washington Senators ballclub | newspaper = Washington Post | location = Washington DC | date = 2013-01-20 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/inauguration/inaugural-parades-announcer-knows-how-to-call-em-as-voice-of-old-senators-team/2013/01/20/945829ac-6279-11e2-b05a-605528f6b712_story.html | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref> [[Barack Obama]]'s [[Second inauguration of Barack Obama|second inauguration]] in 2013 was the 15th consecutive ceremony that Brotman has announced, and his 16th overall.<ref name="sage">{{cite web | title = Sage Communications' Senior Advisor Charlie Brotman to Serve as the President's Announcer for the 57th Inaugural Parade | publisher = Sage Communications | date = 2013-01-14 | url = http://www.aboutsage.com/news/sage-communications-senior-advisor-charlie-brotman-serve-presidents-announcer-57th-inaugural-pa | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref>
During the presidency of [[George W. Bush]], Brotman also served as the announcer at [[tee ball]] games on the South Lawn of the White House.<ref name="whitehouse">{{cite news | title = White House South Lawn Tee Ball | publisher = The White House (archived) | date = 2006-07-30 | url = https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/07/20060724-1.html | accessdate = 2013-01-21}}</ref>
President [[Donald Trump]]'s Presidential Inauguration Committee ended Brotman's reign as announcer, instead picking Steve Ray, a Trump supporter, for the [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|58th Presidential Inauguration]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/08/politics/donald-trump-charles-brotman-inauguration-announcer/index.html|title=Trump drops inauguration announcer who's done them all since Eisenhower|last=CNN|first=Eric Bradner|website=CNN|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> Brotman was, however, selected to welcome the National Organizers for the [[2017 Women's March|Women's March on Washington]] on January 21, 2017 - the day following the Inauguration.<ref>{{Citation|last=ABC News|title=Women's March on Washington 2017 (FULL EVENT) {{!}} ABC News|date=2017-01-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rp1FyjB8WXQ|accessdate=2017-01-22|format=YouTube Video}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Brotman, Charlie}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American public relations people]] [[Category:Major League Baseball public address announcers]] [[Category:People from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Public address announcers]] [[Category:University System of Maryland alumni]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Chilean Swedes |native_name = ''Suecos chilenos''
Svenskchilenare |population = 50,000 (est.) (ca. 0.5% of the Swedish population) |popplace = [[Stockholm]], [[Göteborg]], [[Malmö]] |langs = [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Chilean Spanish]] |rels = [[Irreligion]], [[Atheism]], [[Roman Catholicism]], and [[Evangelicalism]] |related = }} '''Chilean Swedes''' are Chilean immigrants in Sweden and citizens of Sweden who are of Chilean ancestry.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} ==Population== It is estimated that some 50,000 people have Chilean background (first and second generation).{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3993&artikel=5642418|year=2012|quote=I dag beräknas det bo ungefär 50 000 med chilensk bakgrund (första och andra generationens invandrare) i Sverige. Källa: Nationalencyklopedin, Migrationsverket, SCB}} Earlier estimations were 45,000 (2008). ==History== ===Origins=== Before the [[1973 Chilean coup d'état]], there were some 90 Chileans in Sweden.http://www.fokus.se/2010/03/en-svensk-katastrof/ Compared to other Latin American countries, Chile had a tradition of democratic rule and relative political stability. The early stages of mass migration were mainly consistent of politicians, militants, intellectuals and other left-leaning elements seeking political refuge, but recent arrivals usually involve working-class Chileans in search of better living conditions for themselves and their families. Today many live in the bigger cities such as [[Gothenburg]], [[Malmö]] and [[Stockholm]]. Chilean Swedes are the largest and most prominent group among Latin American communities residing in Sweden. ===The Coup 1973=== Chilean people started immigrating in the 1970s in order to escape the dictatorship of [[Augusto Pinochet]]. Sweden was known to be a social democratic country and the government allowed refugees to come to Sweden. But for many the time adapting to the new country was difficult. Language barriers, colder weather and monopolies on TV, radio and alcohol sales, for example, were a huge contrast to Chile. Many who came to Sweden continued to support the overthrown government of [[Salvador Allende]]. When Sweden was scheduled to play a [[Davis Cup]] tennis match against Chile in 1975, a large protest movement instigated by the Chilean diaspora sought to [[boycott]] the match and have it cancelled. The Hoola Bandoola Band even wrote a song titled "Stoppa matchen" ("Stop the match"). Almost 10,000 people demonstrated against the decision to play the match, which was eventually held as scheduled, but without spectators. When [[Milton Friedman]] received his Nobel Prize in 1976, similar protests organized both by Swedes and Chileans were once again seen on the streets. ===After the coup=== During the 1980s, after Pinochet's economic reforms many poverty-stricken Chileans left their home country in hope to seek better opportunities in Sweden, where there was already a sizable presence of Chileans arrived in the previous decade. Some helped the newly arrived so they could integrate in the Swedish society. For a short period immigration from Chile increased after the 1970s and once again peaked. Today Chile is considered to be democratic and prosperous by Latin American standards, which has decreased immigration after the installation of a democratic government in 1990. Chileans who want to visit Sweden can stay three months without a visa thanks to diplomatic agreements between the countries. On the other hand, for Chileans who want to stay permanently in Sweden, it has become much more difficult for them to gain a permanent visa. Since the 1990s, migration from Chile to Sweden has declined following restoration of Chilean democracy and the [[economy of Chile]] growing more successful.{{cite web|url=https://gupea.ub.gu.se/bitstream/2077/30063/1/gupea_2077_30063_1.pdf|title=Från utvandringsland till invandringsland|publisher=School of Public Administration|language=Swedish|author=Osvaldo Salas|date=2009|accessdate=5 February 2017}} The group is considered today to be one of the most well-integrated within Swedish [[society]]. This perception of assimilation resulted in [[Sveriges Radio]] (Swedish Public Radio) to announce that they would stop broadcasting news in Spanish in 2005 [https://web.archive.org/web/20060523034619/http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/sisuradio/nyheter/amnessida.asp?programID=185&Nyheter=1&grupp=2365&artikel=703652]. Most Chilean Swedes are irreligious or atheist, as the first wave consisted mainly of [[Marxism|Marxist]] supporters of Allende, whereas practicing Catholics tended to support Pinochet. Some are Catholics and celebrate Easter, [[Christmas]] and [[New Year]] in the same days as the Swedes. They are the largest Latin American group in Sweden and celebrate their culture in ways such as commemorating [[Chilean Independence Day]] or Fiestas Patrias. Thus they keep alive Chilean folk traditions such as the [[cueca]] and [[huaso]] costumes. ==Notable people== {{multiple image|perrow=3|caption_align=center | image1 = Mauricio_rojas_mullor.JPG|width1=83| caption1 = [[Mauricio Rojas]] | image2 = Malin Diaz 2.jpg|width2=92| caption2 = [[Malin Diaz]] | image3 = Daniel Espinosa.jpg|width3=105| caption3 = [[Daniel Espinosa]] | image4 = Rossana_Dinamarca_2.jpg|width4=102| caption4 = [[Rossana Dinamarca]] | image5 = Miiko_Albornoz.jpg|width5=74| caption5 = [[Miiko Albornoz]] | image6 = Tilde_de_Paula_Eby_in_August_2013.jpg|width6=104| caption6 = [[Tilde de Paula]] }} * [[Luciano Astudillo]], politician active in the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democratic Party]] * [[Sergio Badilla Castillo]], poet * [[Erik Bongcam-Rudloff]], biologist and scientist * [[Sebastian Castro-Tello]], football/soccer player * [[Matias Concha]], football/soccer player * [[Miiko Albornoz]], football/soccer player * [[Malin Diaz]], football/soccer player * [[Rossana Dinamarca]], politician, member of parliament, active in the [[Left Party (Sweden)|Left Party]] * [[Rafael Edholm]], actor Chilean father * [[Daniel Espinosa]], film director, Chilean father * [[Daniela Lincoln Saavedra]], female long jumper * [[Pablo Piñones-Arce]], football/soccer player * [[Mauricio Rojas]], former leftist ([[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|MIR]]) now politician for Folkpartiet ([[Liberal People's Party (Sweden)|Swedish Liberal Party]]) * [[America Vera Zavala]], politician, active in the Left Party * [[The Latin Kings (hip hop group)|The Latin Kings]], rap group from Stockholm ==See also== * [[Chile–Sweden relations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Chilean diaspora}} {{Immigration to Sweden}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish people of Chilean descent| ]] [[Category:Chilean diaspora|Sweden]]

revision.comment: /* Black Economic Empowerment ruling */ a complete misinterpretation of source article. source article also irrelevant to this section.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Chinese South Africans | native_name = 華裔南非人
华裔南非人 | native_name_lang = zh | image = | image_caption = | total = 300 000 - 400 000 | total_year = 2015 | total_source = estimate | total_ref = {{cite journal|last1=Liao|first1=Wenhui|last2=He|first2=Qicai|title=Tenth World Conference of Overseas Chinese: Annual International Symposium on Regional Academic Activities Report (translated)|journal=The International Journal of Diasporic Chinese Studies|date=2015|volume=7|issue=2|pages=85–89}} | regions = [[Durban]]{{·}}[[Johannesburg]]{{·}}[[Port Elizabeth]] | languages = [[English language|English]]{{·}}[[Languages of South Africa|Other Languages of South Africa]]{{·}}[[Yue Chinese|Cantonese]]{{·}}[[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]]{{·}}[[Taiwanese Minnan|Taiwanese Hokkien]] | religions = | related_groups = [[Overseas Chinese]] | footnotes = }} '''Chinese South Africans''' ({{zh|t =華裔南非人|s =华裔南非人}}) are [[overseas Chinese]] who reside in [[South Africa]], including those whose ancestors came to South Africa in the early 20th century until Chinese immigration was banned under the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1904,{{cite web|last=Ho |first=Ufrieda |url=http://www.busrep.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4461881 |title=Chinese locals are black |publisher=Busrep.co.za |date=19 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622150108/http://www.busrep.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4461881 |archivedate=22 June 2008}} Taiwanese industrialists who arrived in the 1970s, 1980s and early 1990s, and post-[[apartheid]] immigrants to South Africa (predominantly from mainland China), who now outnumber locally-born Chinese South Africans.{{cite book | url=http://www.inter-disciplinary.net/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/rei-v1.3b.pdf | work=Representation, Expression and Identity | year=2009 | publisher=Interdisciplinary Perspectives | title=Recent Chinese Migrations to South Africa - New Intersections of Race, Class and Ethnicity | first=Yoon Jung | last=Park | isbn=978-1-904710-81-3 | accessdate=20 September 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228041728/http://www.inter-disciplinary.net/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/rei-v1.3b.pdf | archivedate=28 December 2010 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|last=Leonard|first=Andrew |author-link=Andrew Leonard|url=http://www.salon.com/2008/06/19/chinese_declared_black/|title=What color are Chinese South Africans?|publisher=Salon.com|date=20 June 2008|accessdate=16 March 2017}} South Africa has the largest population of Chinese in Africa, and most of them live in [[Johannesburg]], the "economic hub for all of [[southern Africa]]".{{cite journal|last1=Lin|first1=Edwin|title="Big Fish in a Small Pond": Chinese Migrant Shopkeepers in South Africa|journal=International Migration Review|date=Spring 2014|volume=48|issue=1|pages=181–215|doi=10.1111/imre.12074}} ==History== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em; text-align:right; font-size:95%;" |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#ccf;"| South African Chinese Population, 1904–1936{{cite book|title=Colour, Confusion and Concessions: The History of the Chinese in South Africa|last1=Yap|first1=Melanie|last2=Leong Man|first2=Dainne|year=1996|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|location=Hong Kong|isbn=962-209-423-6|page=510}}{{rp|177}} |- ! Gender || 1904 || 1911 || 1921 || 1936 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:teal;"| [[Natal Province]] |- | Male || 161 || 161 || 75 || 46 |- | Female || 4 || 11 || 33 || 36 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:green;"| [[Cape Province]] |- | Male || 1366 || 804 || 584 || 782 |- | Female || 14 || 19 || 148 || 462 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:#900;"| [[Transvaal Province]] |- | Male || 907 || 905 || 828 || 1054 |- | Female || 5 || 5 || 160 || 564 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:#900;"| |- | '''Total''' || 2457 || 1905 || 1828 || 2944 |} === First settlers === The first Chinese to settle in South Africa were prisoners, usually [[Debtors' prison|debtors]], exiled from [[Batavia, Dutch East Indies|Batavia]] by the [[Dutch people|Dutch]] to their then newly founded [[Cape Colony|colony]] at [[Cape Town]] in 1660. Originally the Dutch wanted to recruit Chinese settlers to settle in the colony as farmers, thereby helping establish the colony and create a tax base so the colony would be less of a drain on Dutch coffers. However the Dutch failed to find anyone in the Chinese community in Batavia who was prepared to volunteer to go to such a far off place. The first Chinese person recorded by the Dutch to arrive in the Cape was a convict by the name of ''Ytcho Wancho'' (almost certainly a Dutch version of his original Chinese name). There were also some free Chinese in the [[Dutch Cape Colony]]. They made a living through fishing and farming and traded their produce for other required goods.{{cite book|last1=Elphick|first1=Richard|last2=Giliomee|first2=Hermann|title=The Shaping of South African Society, 1652–1840.|date=1979|publisher=Wesleyan University Press|isbn=9780819562111|page=223|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=vZqJBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA223|accessdate=1 January 2016}} From 1660 until the late 19th century the number of Chinese people in the Cape Colony never exceeded 100.{{rp|5–6}} Chinese people began arriving in large numbers in South Africa in the 1870s{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article4168245.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=We agree that you are black South African court tells Chinese | first=Jonathan | last=Clayton | date=19 June 2008 | accessdate=28 April 2010}} through to the early 20th century initially in hopes of making their fortune on the diamond and gold mines in [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]] and the [[Witwatersrand Basin|Witwatersrand]] respectively. Most were independent immigrants mostly coming from [[Guangdong Province]] then known as Canton. Due to anti-Chinese feeling and racial discrimination at the time they were prevented from obtaining mining contracts and so became entrepreneurs and small business owners instead.{{cite web | url=http://www.migrationpolicy.org/article/living-between-chinese-south-africa/ | title=Living In Between: The Chinese in South Africa | publisher=Immigration Information Source | date=January 2012 | accessdate=12 January 2012 | author=Park, Yoon Jung}} The Chinese community in South Africa grew steadily throughout the remainder of the 19th century, bolstered by new arrivals from China. The [[Anglo-Boer War]], fought between 1898 and 1902, pushed some Chinese South Africans out of the Witwatersrand and into areas such as [[Port Elizabeth]] and [[East London, Eastern Cape|East London]] in the [[Eastern Cape]].{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Karen L.|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/library-resources/articles_papers/kleios/xxvi-1994-chinese-in-SA.htm|title=The Chinese in South Africa: a preliminary overview to 1910|publisher=Sahistory.org.za|date=1994|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626224153/http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/library-resources/articles_papers/kleios/xxvi-1994-chinese-in-SA.htm|archivedate=26 June 2008}} Areas recorded to have Chinese populations moving in to settle at the time include [[Pageview, Gauteng|Pageview]] in Johannesburg that was declared a non-white area in the late 1800s and known as the "Malay Location"{{cite book|author=Mapungubwe Institute for Strategic Reflection|title=Nation Formation and Social Cohesion: An Enquiry into the Hopes and Aspirations of South Africans|date=2015|publisher=Real African Publishers|isbn=9781920655747|page=148|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=ng4iBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA148|accessdate=6 January 2016|language=en}} Large-scale immigration into South Africa during this time was prohibited by the Transvaal Immigration Restriction Act of 1902 and the Cape Chinese Exclusion Act of 1904. A host of discriminatory laws similar to the anti-Chinese laws that sought to restrict trade, land ownership and citizenship were also enacted during this time. These laws were largely made popular by a general [[Yellow Peril|anti-Chinese feeling]] across the [[western world]] during the early 1900s and the arrival of over 60,000 [[indenture]]d Chinese miners after the [[Second Boer War|second Anglo-Boer War]]. These early immigrants arriving between the 1870s and early 1900s are the ancestors of most of South Africa's first Chinese community and number some 10,000 individuals today. ==== Contracted gold miners (1904–1910) ==== [[File:Punch 1903 - Chinese Paul.jpg|right|thumb|220px| ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' cartoon, 1903; The [[Randlord|Rand mine-owners']] employment of [[Chinese South Africans#Contracted gold miners (1904-1910)|Chinese labour]] on the [[Witwatersrand Basin|Transvaal gold mines]] was controversial and contributed to the Liberal victory in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906 elections]].]] [[File:Ten Years of Toryism.jpg|thumb|Liberal Party poster for the [[United Kingdom general election, 1906|1906 UK elections]], claiming that ten years of [[Conservative Party (UK)|Tory]] rule means "South Africa for the Chinese", and a line of Chinese workers.]] [[File:Chinese Mine Workers- South Africa.jpg|right|thumb|250px| Around 4,200 miners at the Simmer and Jack mine on the Witwatersrand, taken between 1904 and 1910.]] There were many complicated reasons why the British chose to import Chinese labour to use on the mines. After the Anglo-Boer War, production on the gold mines of the Witwatersrand was very low due to a lack of labour. The British government was eager to get these mines back online as quickly as possible as part of their overall effort to rebuild the war-torn country. Because of the war, unskilled black laborers had returned to rural areas and were more inclined to work on rebuilding infrastructure as mining was more dangerous. Unskilled white labour was being phased out because it was deemed too expensive. The British found recruiting and importing labour from east Asia the most expedient way to solve this problem.{{rp|104}} Between 1904 and 1910, over 63,000 contracted miners were brought in to work the mines of the Witwatersrand. Most of these contractors were recruited from the provinces of Chihli ([[Zhili Province|Zhili]]), Shantung ([[Shandong]]) and Honan ([[Henan]]) in China.{{rp|105}} They were repatriated after 1910,{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2008/06/19/in-south-africa-chinese-is-the-new-black/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=In South Africa, Chinese is the New Black | date=19 June 2008}} because of strong White opposition to their presence, similar to [[Yellow Peril|anti-Asian sentiments]] in the western United States, particularly [[California]] at the same time.[[Nativism (politics)#Anti-Chinese nativism]] It is a myth that the contracted miners brought into South Africa at this time are the forefathers of much of South Africa's Chinese population.{{rp|103–104}} [[Herbert Hoover]], who would become the 31st U.S. President, was a director of [[Chinese Engineering and Mining Corporation]] (CEMC) when it became a supplier of [[coolie]] (Asian) labor for South African mines.[[Walter Liggett]], ''The Rise of Herbert Hoover'' (New York, 1932) The first shipment of 2,000 coolies arrived in Durban from [[Qinhuangdao]] in July 1904. By 1906, the total number of Chinese coolies increased to 50,000, almost entirely recruited and shipped by CEMC. When the living and working conditions of the laborers became known, public opposition to the scheme grew and questions were asked in the British Parliament.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/people/mr-winston-churchill/1906|title=Mr Winston Churchill: speeches in 1906 (Hansard)|publisher=Hansard.millbanksystems.com|accessdate=16 March 2017}} The scheme was abandoned in 1911. The mass importation of Chinese labourers to work on the gold mines contributed to the fall from power of the [[Unionist Government 1895–1905|conservative government]] in the United Kingdom. However, it did stimulate to the economic recovery of South Africa after the Anglo-Boer War by once again making the mines of the Witwatersrand the most productive gold mines in the world.{{rp|103}} ===Passive resistance campaign (1906–1913)=== [[File:Chinese Passive Resistance leader.jpg|thumb|Chinese passive resistance leaders circa 1906]] In 1906, about 1000 Chinese joined Indian protesters led by [[Mahatma Gandhi]] to march against laws barring Asians in the [[Transvaal Colony]] from purchasing land.{{cite web|last1=Jain|first1=Ankur|title=Why Mahatma Gandhi is becoming popular in China - BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-25942584|website=BBC News|accessdate=4 January 2016|language=en-GB|date=1 February 2014|quote=Some 1,000 Chinese supporters joined Indians to take part in Gandhi's first peaceful protest in Transvaal province in 1906 to protest against a law that barred Asians from owning property and made it mandatory to carry identity cards, among other things.}}{{cite web|title=Chinese had joined Mahatma Gandhi's South Africa struggle - Times of India|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Chinese-had-joined-Mahatma-Gandhis-South-Africa-struggle/articleshow/42765739.cms|website=The Times of India|accessdate=4 January 2016|date=18 September 2014}} In 1907, the government of the Transvaal Colony passed the [[Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act]] that required the Indian and Chinese populations in the Transvaal to be registered and for males to be fingerprinted and carry [[Pass laws|pass books]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/node/11308|title=Asiatic Law Amendment Act is passed in Transvaal parliament leading to increased Indian protest under MK Gandhi|website=South African History Online|date=22 March 1907|accessdate=4 January 2016|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140623044607/http://www.sahistory.org.za/node/11308|archivedate=23 June 2014}} The Chinese Association made a written declaration saying that the Chinese would not register for passes and would not interact with those that did.{{cite book|editor-last1=Thampi |editor-first1=Madhavi |chapter=Gandhi and the Chinese Community |last=Bhattacharjea |first=Mira Sinha |title=India and China in the colonial world |date=2005 |publisher=Social Science Press |location=New Delhi |isbn=8187358203 |page=160}} Mahatma Gandhi started a campaign of [[passive resistance]] to protest the legislation that was supported by the Indian and Chinese communities. The secretary of the Chinese Association informed Gandhi that the Chinese were prepared to be jailed alongside Indians in support of this cause. On 16 August 1908, members of the movement gathered outside Hamidia Mosque where they burnt 1,200 registration certificates.{{cite web|url=http://www.joburg.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7691:tracing-gandhi-in-joburg&catid=88:news-update&Itemid=266|title=Tracing Gandhi in Joburg|website=joburg.org.za|date=1 February 2012|accessdate=16 March 2017|quote=It was outside the Hamidia Mosque on 16 August 1908 that Indians and Chinese set alight more than 1 200 registration certificates...}} === Apartheid era (1948–1994) === As with other non-White South Africans, the Chinese suffered from discrimination during [[History of South Africa in the apartheid era|apartheid]], and were often classified as [[Coloureds]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7461099.stm|work=BBC News|title=S Africa Chinese 'become black'|date=18 June 2008|accessdate=28 April 2010}} but sometimes as [[Asians in South Africa|Asians]], a category that was generally reserved for [[Indian South Africans]]. Today this segment of the South African Chinese population numbers some 10,000 individuals. Under the [[apartheid]]-era [[Population Registration Act, 1950]], Chinese South Africans were deemed "Asiatic", then "Coloured", and finally: {{blockquote|the Chinese Group, which shall consist of persons who in fact are, or who, except in the case of persons who in fact are members of a race or class or tribe referred to in paragraph (1), (2), (3), (5) or (6) are generally accepted as members of a race or tribe whose national home is in China.{{cite magazine|last=Perry|first=Alex|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1828432,00.html?iid=sphere-inline-sidebar|title=A Chinese Color War|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|location=Johannesburg|date=1 August 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102200551/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1828432%2C00.html?iid=sphere-inline-sidebar|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}}} Chinese South Africans, along with Black, Coloured and Indian South Africans, were forcefully removed from areas declared "Whites only" areas by the government under the [[Group Areas Act]] in 1950. Suburbs in Johannesburg with Chinese South African populations that were subject to forced removals include [[Sophiatown]] starting in 1955,{{cite book|last1=Ansell|first1=Gwen|title=Soweto Blues: Jazz, Popular Music, and Politics in South Africa|date=28 September 2004|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|isbn=978-0826416629|page=67|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=_fwkCIKoTpgC|accessdate=15 December 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Otzen|first1=Ellen|title=The town destroyed to stop black and white people mixing|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-31379211|website=BBC News|accessdate=15 December 2015|date=11 February 2015}} [[Marabastad]] in 1969{{cite book|last1=Accone|first1=Darryl|title=All under heaven : the story of a Chinese family in South Africa|date=2004|publisher=David Philip|location=Claremont, South Africa|isbn=9780864866486|page=251|edition=2. impr.|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=vNt89-7Eq3kC&pg=PA251#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 January 2016}}{{cite news|last=Masilela|first=Johnny|title=The broken miracle of Marabastad|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2014-12-30-the-broken-miracle-of-marabastad|website=Mail and Guardian|date=1 January 2015|accessdate=17 December 2015|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102035958/http://mg.co.za/article/2014-12-30-the-broken-miracle-of-marabastad|archivedate=2 January 2015}} and the adjacent suburbs of [[Pageview, Gauteng|Pageview]] and [[Vrededorp, Gauteng|Vrededorp]], known colloquially as 'Fietas', in 1968.{{cite web|last=Mamdoo|first=Feizel|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2015-09-23-fietas-streets-by-any-other-name-are-not-as-sweet|title=Fietas streets by any other name are not as sweet|website=Mail and Guardian|date=24 September 2015|accessdate=17 December 2015|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150927211022/http://mg.co.za/article/2015-09-23-fietas-streets-by-any-other-name-are-not-as-sweet|archivedate=27 September 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Ho|first1=Ufrieda|title=Fietas vanished like dream|url=http://sbeta.iol.co.za/the-star/fietas-vanished-like-dream-1361831|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222115234/http://sbeta.iol.co.za/the-star/fietas-vanished-like-dream-1361831|archivedate=22 December 2015|website=IOL|publisher=The Star|accessdate=17 December 2015|date=14 August 2012}} Chinese South Africans were also among those removed from the South End district of [[Port Elizabeth]] beginning in 1965.{{cite web|title=South End Museum, Port Elizabeth|url=http://www.southafrica.net/za/en/articles/entry/article-southafrica.net-south-end-museum-port-elizabeth|website=www.southafrica.net|accessdate=2 January 2016}} These removals resulted in the formation of a Chinese township in Port Elizabeth.{{cite book|last1=Saff|first1=Grant R.|title=Changing Cape Town : urban dynamics, policy and planning during the political transition in South Africa|date=1998|publisher=University Press of America|location=Lanham, Md|isbn=978-0761811992|page=60|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=RPmwr-QB3P8C&pg=PA60|accessdate=2 January 2016}} In 1966 the [[South African Institute of Race Relations]] described the negative effects of apartheid legislation on the Chinese community and the resulting [[brain drain]]: {{blockquote|No group is treated so inconsistently under South Africa's race legislation. Under the [[Immorality Act]] they are Non-White. The Group Areas Act says they are Coloured, subsection Chinese ... They are frequently mistaken for Japanese in public and have generally used White buses, hotels, cinemas and restaurants. But in Pretoria, only the consul-general's staff may use White buses .. Their future appears insecure and unstable. Because of past and present misery under South African laws, and what seems like more to come in the future, many Chinese are emigrating. Like many Coloured people who are leaving the country, they seem to favour [[Canada]]. Through humiliation and statutory discrimination South Africa is frustrating and alienating what should be a prized community.{{rp|389–390}}}} In 1928, the liquor legislation was amended to allow Indian South Africans to purchase liquor.{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/politics-and-society/apartheid-legislation-1850s-1970s|title=Apartheid Legislation 1850s-1970s|website=South African History Online|accessdate=2 January 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909040258/http://www.sahistory.org.za/politics-and-society/apartheid-legislation-1850s-1970s|archivedate=9 September 2011|quote=The Liquor Bill Section 104 of the Liquor Bill of 1928 Prohibiting Indians from entering licensed premises is withdrawn.}}{{cite web|title=The Liquor Laws Amendment Bill comes into effect|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/dated-event/liquor-laws-amendment-bill-comes-effect|website=South African History Online|accessdate=2 January 2016|quote=Section 104 of the liquor bill was withdrawn, and Indians were once again allowed to enter licensed premises. Despite this, Africans were still not allowed to buy beer legally.}} Following an amendment in 1962, other non-white South Africans could purchase alcohol, but not drink in white areas.{{cite web|last=Naidoo|first=Aneshree|title=Long reign of the South African shebeen queen|url=http://www.mediaclubsouthafrica.com/culture/3975-long-reign-of-the-south-african-shebeen-queen|website=Media Club South Africa|accessdate=2 January 2016|date=12 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327153224/http://www.mediaclubsouthafrica.com/culture/3975-long-reign-of-the-south-african-shebeen-queen|archivedate=27 March 2015|quote=The Act had restricted profits for commercial brewers, and in 1962 the apartheid government caved under pressure from the industry and opened up sales to black South Africans. They could not drink in town – white areas – but they could now buy commercial beer at off-sales.}} In 1976, the law was amended to allow Chinese South Africans to drink alcohol in white areas.{{cite book|last1=Osada|first1=Masako|title=Sanctions and honorary whites : diplomatic policies and economic realities in relations between Japan and South Africa|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn. [u.a.]|isbn=0313318778|page=163|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XmD52sveLMEC&pg=PP2&lpg=PP2&dq=Sanctions+and+Honorary+White,+Masako+Osada#v=snippet&q=1984%20Japanese%20Chinese&f=false|quote=As of 14 May 1976, Chinese were treated as whites in terms of the Liquor Act.}} In 1984, the [[Tricameral Parliament]] was established by the government to give Coloured and Indian South Africans a limited influence on South African politics. The Tricameral Parliament was criticised by anti-apartheid groups including the [[United Democratic Front (South Africa)|United Democratic Front]], who promoted a boycott of the Tricameral Parliament elections, as it still excluded Black people and had very little political power in South Africa.{{cite web|last1=Brooks Spector|first1=J|title=The UDF at 30: An organisation that shook Apartheid's foundation|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-08-22-the-udf-at-30-an-organisation-that-shook-apartheids-foundation/#.Vofx-qg0WSo|website=Daily Maverick|accessdate=2 January 2016}} The Chinese South African community refused to participate in this parliament.{{cite book|last1=Dubin|first1=Steven C.|title=Spearheading debate : culture wars & uneasy truces|date=2012|publisher=Jacana|location=Auckland Park, South Africa|isbn=978-1431407378|page=225|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=EXbBS63DMq0C&pg=PA225|accessdate=2 January 2016|quote=...and the refusal of the Chinese to participate in the Tricameral Parliament.}} Previously, the Chinese Association had expelled a member who had been appointed to the [[Senate of South Africa#Abolition of the Senate|President's Council]], a body established to advise on constitutional reform.{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=David|title=The White Tribe of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LgwWMUbyNVUC&pg=PA279|accessdate=2 October 2016|year=1983|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-05066-2|pages=279–281}} ===Immigration from Taiwan=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em; text-align:right; font-size:95%;" |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#ccf;"| Number of Chinese granted
permanent residence
in South Africa
1985–1995{{rp|419}} | '''Date''' || '''Number''' |- | 1985 || 1 |- | 1986 || 7 |- | 1987 || 133 |- | 1988 || 301 |- | 1989 || 483 |- | 1990 || 1422 |- | 1991 || 1981 |- | 1992 || 275 |- | 1993 || 1971 |- | 1994 || 869 |- | 1995 || 350 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:#900;"| |- | '''Total''' || '''7793''' |} {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em; text-align:right; font-size:95%;" |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#ccf;"| By citizenship 1994–95{{rp|419}} |- | '''Citizenship''' || '''1994''' || '''1995''' |- | [[Taiwan|Taiwan (ROC)]] || 596 || 232 |- | [[China|People's Republic of China]] || 252 || 102 |- | [[Hong Kong]] || 21 || 16 |- ! scope="row" colspan="5" style="color:#900;"| |- | '''Total''' || 869 || 350 |} With the establishment of ties between [[apartheid South Africa]] and [[Taiwan]] (officially the Republic of China), Taiwanese (as well as some Hong Kong Chinese) started migrating to South Africa from the late 1970s onwards. Due to apartheid South Africa's desire to attract their investment in South Africa and the many poorer [[Bantustans]] within the country, they were exempt from many apartheid laws and regulations. This created an odd situation whereby South Africans of Chinese descent continued to be classified as Coloureds or Asians, whereas the Taiwanese Chinese{{cite journal|url=http://taiwanreview.nat.gov.tw/ct.asp?xitem=123749&ctnode=1360&mp=1|title=Premier Sun visits four African countries|journal=Taiwan Review|date=5 January 1980|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207175931/http://taiwanreview.nat.gov.tw/ct.asp?xitem=123749&ctnode=1360&mp=1|archivedate=7 February 2012}} and certain other east Asian [[expatriate]]s (esp. South [[Koreans]] and Japanese) were considered "[[honorary whites]]" and enjoyed most, if not all, of the rights accorded to [[White South Africans]]. The South African government also offered a number of economic incentives to investors from Taiwan seeking to set up factories and businesses in the country. These generous incentives ranged from "paying for relocation costs, subsidised wages for seven years, subsidised commercial rent for ten years, housing loans, cheap transport of goods to urban areas, and favourable exchange rates". In 1984, South African Chinese, now increased to about 10,000, finally obtained the same official rights as the Japanese in South Africa, that is, to be treated as whites in terms of the Group Areas Act. The arrival of the Taiwanese resulted in a surge of the ethnic Chinese population of South Africa, which climbed from around 10,000 in the early 1980s to at least 20,000 in the early 1990s. Many Taiwanese were entrepreneurs who set up small companies, particularly in the textile sector, across South Africa. It is estimated that by the end of the early 1990s Taiwanese industrialists had invested $2 billion (or $2.94 billion in 2011 dollars)[http://www.measuringworth.com/ Measuring Worth], Relative Value of a U.S. Dollar Amount - [[Consumer Price Index]], retrieved on the 26 January 2011 in South Africa and employed roughly 50,000 people.{{rp|427}} In the late 1990s and early first decade of the 21st century many of the Taiwanese left South Africa partly due to official recognition of the [[People's Republic of China]] and a post apartheid [[Crime in South Africa|crime wave]] that swept the country. Numbers dropped from a high of around 30,000 Taiwanese citizens in the mid-1990s to the current population of approximately 6,000 today. ===Post-Apartheid=== Following the end of [[apartheid]] in 1994, mainland Chinese began immigrating to South Africa in large numbers, increasing the Chinese population in South Africa to an estimated 300,000-400,000 in 2015. In Johannesburg, in particular, a new [[Chinatown]] has emerged in the eastern suburbs of [[Cyrildene]] and [[Bruma, Gauteng|Bruma Lake]], replacing the declining one in the city centre. A Chinese housing development has also been established in the small town of [[Bronkhorstspruit, Gauteng|Bronkhorstspruit]], east of [[Pretoria]],{{full citation needed|date=August 2013}} as well as a massive new “city” in development in Johannesburg. ====Black Economic Empowerment ruling==== Under [[apartheid]], some Chinese South Africans were discriminated against in various forms by the apartheid government. However, they were originally excluded from benefiting under the [[Black Economic Empowerment]] (BEE) programmes of the new [[South African government]]. This changed in mid-2008 when, in a case brought by the Chinese Association of South Africa, the Pretoria division of the [[High Court of South Africa]] ruled that Chinese South Africans who were [[South African nationality law|South African citizens]] before 1994, as well as their descendants, qualify as previously disadvantaged individuals as [[Coloureds]], and therefore are eligible to benefit under BEE and other [[affirmative action]] policies and programmes. The Chinese Association of South Africa was represented by human rights lawyer [[George Bizos]] in court during the case.{{cite web|title=Chinese qualify for BEE|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Chinese-qualify-for-BEE-20080618|website=News24|accessdate=15 December 2015|date=18 June 2008}} However, Chinese South Africans who immigrated to the country after 1994 will be ineligible to benefit under the policies. In September 2015, [[Department of Trade and Industry (South Africa)|Department of Trade and Industry]] deputy director general Sipho Zikode clarified who the ruling was meant to benefit. He said that not all Chinese in South Africa were eligible for BEE. He confirmed that only Chinese who were South African citizens prior to 1994, numbering "about 10,000" were eligible.{{cite web|last1=Mashego|first1=Penelope|title=State defends BEE benefits for Chinese|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/business/2015/09/18/state-defends-bee-benefits-for-chinese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918180214/http://www.bdlive.co.za/business/2015/09/18/state-defends-bee-benefits-for-chinese|archivedate=2015-09-18|website=BdLive|accessdate=20 December 2015|date=18 September 2015}} ==Immigration of Mainland Chinese== [[File:Piketberg.jpg|right|thumb|200px| A "China shop" in [[Porterville, Western Cape|Porterville]], [[Western Cape]], South Africa in 2010. Since the early 2000s many such shops, usually general dealers, have opened up in rural areas by Chinese immigrants from mainland China.]] The immigration of [[mainland Chinese]], by far the largest group of Chinese in South Africa, can be divided into three periods. The first group arrived in the late 1980s and early 1990s along with the Taiwanese immigrants. Unlike the Taiwanese immigrants, lacking the capital to start larger firms, most established small businesses. Although becoming relatively prosperous a large number of this group left South Africa, either back to China or to more developed Western countries, around the same time and for much the same reason as the Taiwanese immigrants left. The second group, arriving mostly from [[Jiangsu]] and [[Zhejiang]] provinces in the 1990s, were wealthier, better educated, and very entrepreneurial. The latest and ongoing group began arriving after 2000 and primarily made up of small traders and peasants from [[Fujian]] province.Y. J. Park and A. Y. Chen, "Intersections of race, class and power: Chinese in post-apartheid Free State", unpublished paper presented at the South African Sociological Association Congress, Stellenbosch, July 2008. There are also many Chinese from other regions in China. As of 2013, there were 57 different regional Chinese associations operating in the Cyrildene Chinatown.{{cite web|last=Ho|first=Ufrieda|title=The arch angle on booming Chinatown|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-07-12-the-arch-angle-on-booming-chinatown|website=Mail and Guardian Online|date=12 July 2013|accessdate=6 January 2016|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714131834/http://mg.co.za/article/2013-07-12-the-arch-angle-on-booming-chinatown|archivedate=14 July 2013}} Although the Chinese South African community is a most law-abiding community that has maintained a low profile in modern South Africa, there is speculation that local criminal gangs in South Africa barter [[abalone]] illegally with Chinese nationals and [[Triad (underground society)|triad societies]] in exchange for chemicals used in the production of drugs, reducing the need for the use of money and hence avoiding difficulties associated with [[money laundering]].{{cite web|url=http://www.capeargus.co.za/?fSectionId=3571&fArticleId=vn20090411065235212C189274|title=Cape Argus|publisher=Cape Argus|date=11 April 2009|accessdate=29 July 2010}}{{dead link|date=October 2016}}{{cbignore}}{{cite web|format=PDF|last=Gastrow|first=Peter|url=https://issafrica.s3.amazonaws.com/site/uploads/paper48.pdf|title=Triad societies and Chinese organised crime in South Africa, Occasional Paper No 48|publisher=[[Institute for Security Studies|ISS Africa]]|date=2 February 2001|accessdate=16 March 2017}} ==Notable Chinese South Africans== * [[Patrick Soon-Shiong]] (黃馨祥), surgeon and billionaire * [[Chad Ho]], six-time titleholder for the [[Midmar Mile]] * [[Chris Wang]] (王翊儒), former member of the [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]], originally an MP for the [[Independent Democrats|ID]], now a member of the [[African National Congress|ANC]] * [[Eugenia Chang]], member of the [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]], for the [[Inkatha Freedom Party]] * [[Ina Lu]] (呂怡慧), Miss Chinese International 2006 * [[Sherry Chen (politician)|Sherry Chen]] (陈阡蕙), former Member of Parliament in South Africa, member of the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] * [[Shiaan-Bin Huang]] (黄士豪), Member of Parliament of South Africa, member of the [[African National Congress]] ==See also== *[[Chinatowns in Africa]] *[[Asians in South Africa]] *[[History of South Africa]] *[[Overseas Chinese]] *[[Nan Hua Temple]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|title=Colour, Confusion & Concessions: The History of the Chinese in South Africa|last=Yap|first=Melanie|author2=Man, Dianne|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=1996|isbn=962-209-424-4}} *{{cite book|title=A Matter of Honour: Being Chinese in South Africa|last=Park|first=Yoon Jung|publisher=Jacana Media (Pty) Ltd|year=2008|isbn=978-1-77009-568-7|edition=Paperback}} *{{cite book|title=Chinese Labour in South Africa, 1902-10: Race, Violence, and Global Spectacle|last=Bright|first=Rachel|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2013|isbn=978-0-230-30377-5}} ==External links== * http://en.nanhuatemple.org/ * http://www.tcagp.co.za {{Ethnic groups in South Africa}} {{Overseas Chinese}} [[Category:Asian South African]] [[Category:Chinese diaspora in Africa|South Africa]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in South Africa]] [[Category:1904 in South Africa]] [[Category:South African people of Chinese descent| ]] [[Category:Chinese South African| ]]

revision.comment: /* Book reviews */the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{italics title}} {{Orphan|date=May 2014}}
'''''Fatal Misconception: The Struggle to Control World Population''''' is a 2008 book by Matthew Connelly, an associate professor of history at [[Columbia University]].
Efforts to [[birth control|control population]] have been controversial, and Connelly argues that "the road to controlling [[population growth]] in the 20th century was [[the road to hell is paved with good intentions|paved with good intentions]] and unpleasant policies that did not work". For example, millions of [[intrauterine contraceptive]] devices were exported to poor countries although they were known to cause infections and sterility.<ref name=kristof/>
==Reception==
===Book reviews===
[[Nicholas Kristof]] reviewed the book favorably for ''[[The New York Times]]'', but concluded: "It’s certainly fair of Connelly to dredge up the forced sterilizations, the casual disregard for injuries caused by IUDs, the racism and sexism and all the rest — but we also need to remember that all that is history. The family planning movement has corrected itself, and today it saves the lives of women in poor countries and is central to efforts to reduce poverty worldwide. If we allow that past to tarnish today’s efforts by family planning organizations, women in poor countries will be doubly hurt."<ref name=kristof>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/23/books/review/Kristof-t.html|title = Birth Control for Others|date = March 23, 2008|accessdate = February 11, 2014|last = Kristof|first = Nicholas|authorlink = Nicholas Kristof}}</ref>
[[Reihan Salam]] reviewed the book for the ''[[New York Sun]]'', where he raised some cautionary points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/birth-control/73199/|title = Book Review: Fatal Misconception by Matthew Connelly|last = Salam|first = Reihan|authorlink = Reihan Salam|date = March 19, 2008|accessdate = February 11, 2014|publisher = ''[[New York Sun]]''}}</ref>
[[James Hughes (sociologist)|James Hughes]], executive director of the [[Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies]] (IEET) reviewed the book for ''[[Times Higher Education]]''. Hughes concluded: "Connelly's pessimism that international institutions can ever be as accountable as national governments is hopefully unwarranted. It seems likely that transnational bodies will be increasingly important in ensuring the health and wellbeing of the nine or ten billion people the planet will soon hold."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/402168.article|title = Fatal Misconception: The Struggle to Control World Population|last = Hughes|first = James|authorlink = James Hughes (sociologist)|publisher = ''[[Times Higher Education]]''|date = May 29, 2008|accessdate = February 11, 2014}}</ref>
[[Helen Epstein]] reviewed the book favorably for the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', concluding: "The population control movement was a small part of US foreign policy, but its history reminds us of the point American policymakers keep missing: universal human rights are not a luxury. They are themselves the goals we should be seeking."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.powells.com/review/2008_08_18.html |title=The Strange History of Birth Control |last=Epstein |first=Helen |authorlink=Helen Epstein |date=August 18, 2008 |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |publisher=''[[New York Review of Books]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222201504/http://www.powells.com/review/2008_08_18.html |archivedate=February 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
Diana Wyndham reviewed the book for the ''[[Australian Review of Public Affairs]]'', concluding: "Connelly’s apparent balance—he opposes both pro- and anti-population control excesses—means he is more likely to reach and convince a broader audience to accept his argument that global population control services are bad and should cease. A major worry is that this book’s catalogue of failed population control programs will be used by ‘Pro-life’ groups who want to reinstate the 1984 Mexico City policy ban which, by denying aid, spread sexually transmitted diseases and increased pregnancy-related deaths. If, as he believes, ‘the heroic age of population control is over’ (p. 16), life on this planet will end because there is only a finite supply of water, food and natural resources. There is wisdom in the family planning slogan: ‘Hope is not a method’."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianreview.net/digest/2009/04/wyndham.html|title = Forget Population Control – All You Need is Love|date = April 2009|accessdate = February 11, 2014|publisher = ''[[Australian Review of Public Affairs]]''|last = Wyndham|first = Diana}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:2008 books]] [[Category:American history books]] [[Category:History books about medicine]] [[Category:Medical controversies]]

revision.comment: Corrected phraseology. It previously said "United States District Attorney" instead of "United States Attorney" (which is the correct title).
revision.text:
'''Gretchen C. F. Shappert''' was United States Attorney for the [[United States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina|western district of North Carolina]] from 2004-2009.
Shappert stressed tough prosecution of drug offenders while in office.<ref>[http://www.cityofgastonia.com/city_serv/police/_pdf%20files/WATSON.pdf article on Shappert's plans for full prosecution of drug offenders]</ref> Shappert also served as chair of the Justice Department's subcommitee on [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] issues.<ref>[http://indian.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Hearings.Testimony&Hearing_ID=a0fd16ca-23f2-4075-a044-196378eec19f&Witness_ID=c1ed6436-28af-41c7-894b-d90db72df000 Report on Native American affairs]</ref> Shappert also opposed retroactively lessening prison sentences related to [[crack-cocaine]].<ref>[http://www.icjia.state.il.us/public/index.cfm?metasection=Publications&metapage=CJN_cocdisp032708&printerfriendly article on crack cocaine sentencing guidelines]</ref>
Shappert passed the North Carolina bar in 1980. She graduated from Duke University in 1977, and from Washington and Lee Law School. She was in private practice and was an assistant district attorney and an assistant public defender in [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]] before becoming a federal prosecutor.
Shappert resigned as U.S. Attorney in March 2009.
==Sources== *[http://judiciary.house.gov/judiciary/hearings/pdf/Shappert080226.pdf Transcript of testimony of Shappert before House Judiciary Committee] {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shappert, Gretchen}} [[Category:North Carolina lawyers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:United States Attorneys for the Western District of North Carolina]] [[Category:Public defenders]]
{{NorthCarolina-stub}}

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:FrescoBot/Links|link syntax]] and minor changes
revision.text:
{{infobox ethnic group| |group= Shaikh |population = 1,084,000<ref>http://www.joshuaproject.net/people-profile.php?peo3=18084&rog3=IN</ref> |popplace = • {{flagcountry|India}} • {{flagcountry|Pakistan}} |langs = • [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] • [[Hindi language|Hindi]] • [[Urdu language|Urdu]] |rels= • [[Image:Allah-green.svg|18px]] [[Islam]] 100% • |related= • [[Sindhi Shaikh]] • [[Shaikh of Rajasthan]] • [[Shaikhs in South Asia|Shaikh]] }}
The Shaikh are a [[Muslim]] community found in the state of [[Gujarat]] in [[India]]. They are part of the larger [[Shaikhs in South Asia|Shaikh]] community of [[South Asia]]. Included within the Shaikh community are the [[Shaikhda]] of [[Bharuch district]] and the Sodagar of [[Patan, Gujarat|Patan]].<ref name="ReferenceA">People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part Three edited by R.B Lal, P.B.S.V Padmanabham, G Krishnan & M Azeez Mohideen pages 1278-1282</ref>
==History and origin==
The word Shaikh in [[Arabic]] means a tribal elder or headman.
The term Shaikh can cover a community of no definite origin, since the name has been used by any individuals of wide background. Mostly influential people or poor farmers converted by Sufi saints used to adopt Shaikh title.
They played a key role in the early [[Islamic]] history of [[Gujarat]], serving as courtiers and administrators for the [[Gujarat Sultanate|Sultans of Gujarat]] and later [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] rulers. After the breakup of the [[Mughal Empire]], they became rulers of a number of states in the [[Kathiawar]] region, with [[Mangrol, Kathiawar|Mangrol]] being the most important.
The community is found mainly in [[Ahmedabad district|Ahmedabad]], [[Bharuch]], [[Godhra]], [[Vadodara]], [[Rajkot]], [[Junagadh]], [[Bhavnagar]] and the [[Kutch District]]. They are essentially an urban community, except the Shaikh of [[Kutch]]. The [[Kutchi people|Kutchi]] Shaikh have three groups of equal status, the Shaikh Dada, Shaikh Sayed and Shaikh Fakeer. The first two are found in Kanyabee village and the last group in Shaikh Sumrasar village of the [[Bhuj]] [[taluka]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Shaikh by District History & origin==
=== The Hansotis of Bharuch === The Shaikh of [[Bharuch]] include the Hansotis, a unique community, who initially arose from the [[Hansot]] taluka of [[Gujarat]]. The Hansoti dialect, which has often been assigned to a broader language known as "[[Bombay Urdu]]" has an archaic proto-[[Urdu]] character; it has retained Arabic and Turkic words which other Urdu dialects do not.
Modern Hansotis are a product of both indigenous populations, such as [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]]s, [[Rajput]]s and [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]]s, and diverse historic immigration, from countries including [[Yemen]], [[Iraq]], [[Syria]], [[Greater Khorasan|Khorasan]] (Central Asia) and [[Habshi]]s! (North-east Africa).
Prominent people from Hansot include: * [[Shaikh Samad]], who reported directly to the [[Mughal Emperor]] [[Akbar]] (regarding the [[Parsi]] community of [[Navsari]], among other matters); * the actor [[Farooq Sheikh]], and; * cricketer [[Abdulahad Malek]].<ref>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/india/content/player/290721.html ]</ref>
==Present circumstances==
The Shaikh of Gujarat are largely an urban community, with the exception being the Shaikh of [[Kutch]], who are largely farmers. In [[Kutch]], the Shaikh undertake rain fed agriculture, and grow mainly wheat, sorghum and groundnuts. A few rear goat, sheep and cattle. Those in the urban area engage in a number of occupation, and have traditions similar to other [[Gujarati Muslim]]s community. The majority of the Shaikh are [[Sunni]], the only exception being the Shaikh families of the town of [[Khambhat]], who are [[Shia]]. Like other [[Gujarati Muslim]]s, they too have a statewide caste association, the Shaikh Samyukh Mowath Jamat. The Shaikh of [[Gujarat]] have differing native languages depending on their particular ethnogenesis. Some speak [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] with large number of [[Urdu]] loanwords, while those of [[Kutch]] speak [[Kutchi language|Kutchi]]. .,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> & yet others speak archaic proto-Urdu e.g. Hansotis.
==The Sodagar==
The Sodagar or Arab Shaikh are a small sub-group within the larger Shaikh community. They originate from the [[Hadhramaut]] region of [[Yemen]], and settled in the city of [[Patan, Gujarat|Patan]], during the period of [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] rule, and intermarried with the [[Sunni Bohra]] community. The community were involved the buying and selling of silk, and exporting it to the [[Middle East]]. They still maintain links with the [[Middle East]], being fluent in [[Arabic]]. But the Sodagar mohalla in Patan has declined, with many of their houses becoming crumbling ruins. They have their own caste association, the Jamat Shams Sofdagaran, which is involved in the up keep of their jamat khana, in the town of Patan. They are strictly endogamous, and do not marry with other Shaikh groups. There are still cases of intermarriage with [[Arab]] communities in the [[Middle East]].<ref>Muslim Communities in Gujarat by Satish C Misra pages 112-114</ref>
==See also==
* [[Shaikhs in South Asia]] * [[Sindhi Shaikh]]s
==References==
{{reflist}} {{Indian Muslim}}
[[Category:Social groups of Gujarat]] [[Category:Muslim communities of India]] [[Category:Muslim communities of Gujarat]] [[Category:Muhajir communities]] [[Category:Shaikh clans]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Habibullah Fawzi |native_name = |native_name_lang = |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> |alt = |caption = |order = |office = Member of the Afghanistan High Peace Council |term_start = |term_end = |constituency = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |citizenship = Afghanistan |nationality = Afghanistan |party = Taliban |otherparty = <!--For additional political affiliations--> |spouse = |partner = <!--For those with a domestic partner and not married--> |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = |occupation = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = |blank1 = |data1 = |blank2 = |data2 = |blank3 = |data3 = |blank4 = |data4 = |blank5 = |data5 = <!--Military service--> |nickname = |allegiance = |branch = |serviceyears = |rank = |unit = |commands = |battles = |awards = |military_blank1 = |military_data1 = |military_blank2 = |military_data2 = |military_blank3 = |military_data3 = |military_blank4 = |military_data4 = |military_blank5 = |military_data5 = }} '''Habibullah Fawzi''' is a citizen of Afghanistan, who was a senior diplomat during the Taliban's administration of Afghanistan, and was appointed to the [[Afghanistan High Peace Council]] in September 2010.<ref name=Cnn2011-07-16> {{cite news | url = http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-16/world/afghanistan.un.sanctions.taliban_1_taliban-leaders-afghan-government-high-peace-council?_s=PM:WORLD | title = 14 ex-Taliban members removed from U.N. sanctions | publisher = [[CNN]] | author = David Ariosto | date = 2011-07-16 | accessdate = 2011-09-06 | quote = }} </ref><ref name=MembersOfTheHighPeaceCouncil> {{cite web | url = http://www.afghan-bios.info/index.php?option=com_afghanbios&id=686&task=view&total=2411&start=842&Itemid=2 | title = High Peace and Reconcilliation Council | publisher = [[High Peace and Reconcilliation Council]] | date = 2011-12-28 | accessdate = 2012-01-06 }} </ref><ref name=PajhwokHighPeace2010-09-29> {{cite news | url = http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2010/09/29/peace-council-members-named | title = Peace council members named | publisher = [[Pajhwok Afghan News]] | author = Abdul Qadir Siddique | date = 2010-09-29 | accessdate = 2012-01-06 }} </ref><ref name=UNAlQaidaList2003>[[John R. Bolton]], [http://en.wikisource.org/w/index.php?title=Denied_Persons_Pursuant_to_UN_Security_Council_Resolution Denied Persons Pursuant to UN Security Council Resolution], ''[[United States Federal Registry]]'', 2003, accessdate = 2010-11-03</ref><ref> {{cite news | url = http://www.dawn.com/2011/07/16/un-removes-14-taliban-members-from-sanctions-list.html | title = UN removes 14 Taliban members from sanctions list | publisher = [[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] | date =2011-07-16 }} </ref> Fawzi had served as the [[Charge D'Affairs]] at the Taliban's embassy in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name=Rfe2009-01-08> {{cite news | url = http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1079333.html | title = Afghanistan: A First Step Toward 'Turning' Moderate Taliban? | publisher = [[Radio Free Europe]] | date = 2009-01-08 | author = Ron Synovitz | quote = Afghan authorities met with four former senior Taliban leaders, thought to be moderate members of the ousted regime, in a bid to get more hardened fighters to surrender. The Taliban's former unofficial envoy to the UN, Abdul Hakim Mujahid, former Deputy Higher Education Minister Arsullah Rahmani, former Deputy Minister of Refugees Rahmatullah Wahidyar, and Habibullah Fawzi, former charge d'affaires at the Afghan Embassy in Saudi Arabia, met with authorities in Kabul. }} </ref>
On January 7, 2002, ''[[Newsday]]'' described Habibullah as one of the senior Taliban leaders who had defected, went into exile in [[Pakistan]], and were seeking a peaceful role in Afghanistan's politics.<ref name=Newsday2002-01-07> {{cite news | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/98429208.html?dids=98429208:98429208&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+07%2C+2002&author=Mohamad+Bazzi.+STAFF+CORRESPONDENT&pub=Newsday+(Combined+editions)&desc=Taliban+by+Any+Other+Name%3F&pqatl=google | title = Taliban by Any Other Name? | publisher = [[Newsday]] | date = 2002-01-07 | author = Mohamad Bazzi | quote = Their choice of a venue for the December announcement highlighted the presence of many ex-Taliban leaders who not only had sought refuge in Pakistan but also intended to resume political activities. To many analysts, the group's public presence in Pakistan underscored this country's long history of support for the Taliban and Islamabad's uneasiness about the makeup of the new Afghan government. }} </ref> The defectors revived a defunct political party, [[Jamiat Khudamul Furgan]], translated as ''"Association of the servants of the Quran"''.<ref name=DailyExcelsior2002-04> {{cite news |url = http://www.hvk.org/articles/0402/46.html |title = Taliban in a new name? |author = Satyabrata Rai Chowdhuri |publisher = [[Daily Excelsior]] |date = 2002-04-05 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120211233731/http://www.hvk.org/articles/0402/46.html |archivedate = 2012-02-11 |df = }} </ref>
In 2005 Habibullah, and three other former Taliban leaders described as moderates, [[Abdul Hakim Mujahid]], [[Arsullah Rahmani]] and [[Rahmatullah Wahidyar]] met with officials of the Hamid Karzai administration to discuss the possible surrender of active Taliban fighters.<ref name=Rfe2009-01-08/> ''[[Radio Free Europe]]'' interviewed Habibullah in March 2005.<ref name=Rfe2005-03-04> {{cite news | url = http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1057816.html | title = Afghanistan: RFE/RL Interviews Former Taliban Involved In Reconciliation Talks | publisher = [[Radio Free Europe]] | date = 2005-03-04 | author = Sultan Sarwar, Golnaz Esfandiari | quote = Habibullah Fawzi, a former Taliban diplomat at the Afghan Embassy in Riyadh, is one of four senior former Taliban members who have responded to an amnesty offer by the Afghan government. In an exclusive interview with RFE/RL, he explains his motivations and plans for the future. }} </ref> In an interview published on March 4, 2005 ''Radio Free Europe'', Habibullah said that the moderates had been in talks with the Karzai administration for the previous two years.
Habibullah, and the other three men had been named on the [[United Nations]] [[1267 list]], a list of several hundred individuals upon whom member nations were to impose financial sanctions because they were suspected of playing a role in international terrorism.<ref name=UNAlQaidaList2003/> The list was first published in 1999. The United Nations removed Habibullah and the other three men in July 2011.<ref name=Cnn2011-07-16/>
In September 2011 Habibullah was one of the former Taliban officials who offered details as to how a Taliban messenger had assassinated [[Burnahuddin Rabbani]], the former [[President of Afghanistan]] who chaired the High Peace Council.<ref name=Telegraph2011-09-20> {{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/8777646/Turban-bomber-kills-former-Afghan-president.html | title = Turban bomber kills former Afghan president | publisher = [[The Telegraph (UK)]] | date = 2011-09-20 | author = Lianne Gutcher, Dean Nelson }} </ref> {{quotation|“...wearing Afghan style clothes – shalwar kamez and turban – came from Quetta to Kabul with a message of peace from the Taliban. He met Rabbani and Stanekzai. Rabbani was expecting him. He was supposed to be a key member of the Taliban. They discussed peace and after the meeting was over Rabbani stood up to wish this man goodbye. Rabbani and the Talib hugged and that was when he blew himself up.” }}
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fawzi, Habibullah}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Afghan diplomats]] [[Category:Taliban leaders]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:Afghan expatriates in Pakistan]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Han |altname=Samhan |states=[[Samhan]] |region=Southern [[Korea]] |familycolor=altaic |family=[[Koreanic]] |iso3=pkc |linglist2=pkc |glotto=paek1234 }}
The '''Han languages''' ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 한어; 韓語) or '''[[Samhan]] languages''' ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 삼한어; 三韓語) was a branch of the ancient [[Koreanic languages]],<ref name="Indiana"> 2014. Multitree: A digital library of language relationships. Bloomington, IN: Department of Linguistics, The LINGUIST List, Indiana University. http://multitree.org/.</ref><ref>"The World's Major Languages": Edition 2. Bernard Comrie (2017), Routledge</ref><ref name="Frawley"> "International Encyclopedia of Linguistics" (Volume 1) William J. Frawley (2003), Oxford University Press</ref><ref name="Crannell">"Voice and Articulation", Kenneth C. Crannell (2011), Wadsworth Company</ref><ref>"Studies on the phonological system of Korean", Kim Wan-jin (1981), Ilchogak</ref><ref>"Community languages: a handbook", Barbara M. Horvath, Paul Vaughan (1991), Multilingual Matters Ltd</ref> referring to the non-Buyeo Koreanic languages,<ref name="Indiana"></ref> once spoken in the southern [[Korean Peninsula]], which was closely related to the [[Buyeo languages]].<ref name="Crannell"></ref>
The Han languages were spoken in the [[Mahan]], [[Byeonhan]] and [[Jinhan]].<ref name="Frawley"></ref> The extent of Han languages are unclear. It is generally accepted as including [[Sillan language|Sillan]], and may also have included [[Baekje language]].
==Background==
One of the most prominent leader of the Han ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 한; 韓) Immigration was [[King Jun of Gojoseon]] from the northern Korea, having lost the throne to [[Wiman of Gojoseon|Wiman]], fled to the state of [[Jin (Korean state)|Jin]] in southern Korea around 194 - 180 BC.<ref>Gina Lee Barnes,《State Formation in Korea: Historical and Archaeological Perspectives》, Psychology Press, 2001, {{ISBN|0700713239}}, p.29-33</ref> He and his followers established [[Mahan]] which was one of the [[Samhan]] ("Three Hans"), along with [[Byeonhan]] and [[Jinhan]]. Further Han(韓) migration followed the fall of Gojoseon and establishment of the Chinese commanderies in 108 BC.
==See also== *[[Old Korean]] **[[Goguryeo language]] **[[Silla language]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:History of the Korean language]] [[Category:Languages of Korea]] [[Category:Koreanic languages]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nigeria]]; removed {{uncategorized}} using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
Ika
The Ika people are found in Delta and Edo states of southern Nigeria. The '''Ika people''' speak Ika language, a unique language with elements of Benin and Igbo languages. They share borders linguistically in the west with the Edo speakers, in the north with the Ishan speakers, in the East with the Enuani speakers and in the south with the Ukwale speakers.[1]
The Ika people are specifically located in the North-West of Delta State but some of their communities like Igbanke, Inyelen and Ekpon spilled over into Edo State. Ika communities mostly comprise the following: Agbor, Owa, Umunede, Owerre Olubor, Ekuoma, Emuhu, Mbiri, Abavo, Orogodo, Otolokpo, Igbodo, Ute-Okpu, Ute-Ogbeje, Idumuesah, Akumazi, Ekpon (Edo State), Igbanke (Edo State), Inyelen Edo State), Iru (Edo State). Other Ika communities found in Edo State are Owanikeke,Ute Obagie, Owa-Riuzo Idu and Igbogili.
