However, the nude Sims are featureless.<ref>{{cite news | title = 'Sims' content criticized | work = CNNMoney.com| date = 2005-07-28 | url = http://money.cnn.com/2005/07/28/technology/personaltech/sims_rating/ | accessdate = 2010-01-12}}</ref> |- | [[2004 in video gaming|2004]] || ''[[JFK: Reloaded]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Traffic Software || Puts the player in the role of [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] as he [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassinates]] [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[John F. Kennedy]]. Criticized for its controversial content matter in recreating the assassination and was condemned by a spokesman for Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] as "despicable".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/jfk-reloaded-picks-up-press-none-pretty/1100-6113828/|title=JFK Reloaded picks up press, none pretty|first=Curt|last=Feldman|date=23 November 2004|publisher=}}</ref> |- | [[2005 in video gaming|2005]] || ''[[Super Columbine Massacre RPG!]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Danny Ledonne]] || The game simulates the events of the [[Columbine High School massacre]], having the player take on the roles of [[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold]] and acting out the massacre.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holmes | first1=T.J. | first2=Betty | last2=Nguyen|date=November 7, 2007|url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0711/11/sm.01.html|title=Transcripts - CNN Sunday Morning|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=December 10, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Hung, Yee|date=June 12, 2007|title=Exploiting grief; bad taste, it appears, makes money|work=[[The Straits Times]]|page=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Thompson, Clive|date=July 23, 2006|title=Saving The World, One Video Game At a Time |work=[[The New York Times]]|page=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Townsend, Emru |date=October 23, 2006 |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/127579-3/the_10_worst_games_of_all_time.html |title=The 10 Worst Games of All Time |work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |accessdate=October 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081104103228/http://www.pcworld.com/article/127579-3/the_10_worst_games_of_all_time.html |archivedate=November 4, 2008 |df= }}</ref> |- | [[2005 in video gaming|2005]] || ''[[Gun (video game)|Gun]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[GameCube]], [[Xbox 360]] || [[Activision]] || The game's offensive depictions of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indians]] prompted the Association for American Indian Development to call a boycott against the game.<ref>[http://asia.gamespot.com/xbox/action/gun/news/6143508/american-indian-group-boycotts-gun?mode=news] {{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |- | [[2005 in video gaming|2005]] || ''[[The Punisher (2005 video game)|The Punisher]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] || [[Volition (company)|Volition]] || Interrogation, torture, intense gun fights, drugs, and killing with no mercy. Originally merited an "Adults Only" rating before being edited on appeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/punisher-/mobyrank |title=The Punisher for PlayStation 2 (2005) MobyRank |publisher=MobyGames |date=2005-01-18 |accessdate=2012-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbbfc.co.uk/CaseStudies/The_Punisher_ |title=Case Study: The Punisher |publisher=Sbbfc.co.uk |accessdate=2012-11-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720013613/http://www.sbbfc.co.uk/CaseStudies/The_Punisher_ |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refused-classification.com/censorship/games/a-to-z-listing.html |title=Games Censorship: A to Z |publisher=Refused-Classification.com |accessdate=2012-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/punisher- |title=The Punisher for PlayStation 2 (2005) |publisher=MobyGames |accessdate=2012-11-02}}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] || ''[[Bully (video game)|Bully]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] [[Xbox 360|360]], [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], [[Wii]], [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Shield Android TV]], [[Shield Tablet]], [[Shield Portable]] || [[Rockstar Games]] || Based upon its title, it was perceived that ''Bully'' glorified [[bullying]]. That the main character Jimmy could also kiss another boy was a matter of controversy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/bullys-boy-on-boy-scenes-causing-a-stir/1100-6160340/ |title=Bully's boy-on-boy scene causing a stir |accessdate=19 March 2007 |last=Sinclair |first=Brendan |date=26 October 2006 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] }}</ref> Classification boards generally restricted ''Bully'' to a teenage audience: the US-based [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] (ESRB) classified the game with a T rating,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esrb.org/ratings/synopsis.jsp?Certificate=21949&Title=Bully&searchkeyword=Bully |title=Bully |publisher=[[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] |date=4 January 2010 |accessdate=27 May 2011}}</ref> the [[British Board of Film Classification]] gave it a 15 rating, the [[Australian Classification Board]] rated it M,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Pages/View.aspx?sid=0SX7BXMuoIalF4idU%2bvOVA%253d%253d&ncdctx=ZQRuMMFQjkjhPsBA2qkGU15hHFs2Hwj4CVSbMtLcbcLpxBsSO9jlBq6HO1GfvnkN |title=Bully (Multi Platform) |work=[[Australian Classification Board]] |publisher=[[Australian Government]] |accessdate=30 June 2014 }}</ref> and the New Zealand [[Office of Film and Literature Classification (New Zealand)|OFLC]] restricted it to persons 13 years of age and over. In 2007, [[Yahoo! Games]] listed it as one of the top ten controversial games of all time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Controversial Games |publisher=[[Yahoo! Games]] |first=Ben |last=Silverman |date=17 September 2007 |url=http://videogames.yahoo.com/feature/controversial-games/530593 |accessdate=19 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429053154/http://videogames.yahoo.com/feature/controversial-games/530593 |archivedate=29 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] || ''[[The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion]]'' || [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 3|PS3]] || [[Bethesda Softworks]] || {{Main|ESRB re-rating of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion}} Re-rated to "Mature" by the ESRB after a third-party mod revealed a nude topless graphic hidden in the game's data files. While the graphic did not warrant a re-rating of the game in and of itself, upon review, the ESRB noted that the game contained much more explicit violence than had been submitted to them in the original rating submission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/editorials/op-ed/797-Boobies-Did-Not-Break-the-Game-The-ESRB-Clears-the-Air-On-Oblivion |title="Boobies Did Not Break the Game": The ESRB Clears the Air On Oblivion |first=Michael |last=Zenke |publisher=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]] |date=2007-06-19 |accessdate=2007-07-02}}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] ||''[[Hitman: Blood Money]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3|PS3]] || [[IO Interactive]] || Violence and assassinations; magazine ads for the game featured pictures depicting murder victims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.gamedaily.com/industry/adwatch/?id=12652 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012163416/http://biz.gamedaily.com/industry/adwatch/?id=12652 |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2009-01-13 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] ||''[[Mind Quiz: Your Brain Coach|Mind Quiz]]'' || [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]] || [[Ubisoft]] || Recalled in the United Kingdom due to use of the word "spastic", which is considered highly offensive in the UK.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hayward |first=Andrew |url=http://www.1up.com/news/mind-quiz-yanked-offensive-term |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622070847/http://www.1up.com/news/mind-quiz-yanked-offensive-term |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-06-22 |title=Mind Quiz Yanked in UK for Offensive Term |publisher=1up.com |date=2007-06-29 |accessdate=2011-10-21 }}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] ||''[[Left Behind: Eternal Forces]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Left Behind Games || Accusations that the game promoted religious "convert or kill" violence, sexism and racism.<ref name="jt fire">{{cite news| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/16/AR2006081601764.html| title = Fire and Brimstone, Guns and Ammo| author = Musgrove, Mike| publisher = The Washington Post| date = 2006-08-17| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6178055.stm| title = Christian video game draws anger| author = Greene, Richard| publisher = BBC| date = 2006-12-14| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/Technology/Story?id=2748351&page=1|title = Faith-Based Killing? Critics Rip Christian Video Game| last1= Tapper | first1=Jake | last2=Miller | first2=Avery| publisher = [[ABC News]]| date = 2006-12-04| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref> Some reviewers<ref>{{cite web|first=Steve|last=Butts |url=http://pc.ign.com/articles/745/745956p1.html |title=IGN: Left Behind: Eternal Forces review |publisher=Pc.ign.com |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kuchera |first=Ben |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/reviews/2006/12/leftbehind.ars |title=Left Behind: Eternal Forces review |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2006-12-13 |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/left-behind-eternal-forces/749748p1.html |title=GameSpy: Left Behind: Eternal Forces review |publisher=Pc.gamespy.com |accessdate=2011-10-21}}</ref> denied that the game contained any truly controversial gameplay. |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] || ''[[Resistance: Fall of Man]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]] || [[Insomniac Games]] || {{Main|Controversy over the use of Manchester Cathedral in Resistance: Fall of Man}} The [[Church of England]] objected to the game's use of [[Manchester Cathedral]]'s interior as a backdrop during a gun battle, and called for the game to be withdrawn or for the cathedral to be removed from the game.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/church-of-england-attacks-use-of-cathedral-in-ps3s-resistance|title = Church of England attacks use of cathedral in PS3's Resistance | author = Bramwell, Tom| publisher = [[Eurogamer]]| date = 2007-06-11| accessdate = 2008-09-13}}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] || ''[[RapeLay]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Illusion Soft]] || Rape is a core part of the gameplay, as the player takes on the role of a [[Chikan (body contact)|chikan]] who stalks, and subsequently rapes a mother and her two daughters, at least one of whom is underage. Three years after its initial release, significant controversy was raised in the UK Parliament and elsewhere, and [[Equality Now]] eventually pressured its distributor to withdraw distribution of it in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2008/03/uk-politician-c/|title=UK Politician Calls Police War On Photography "Daft"|publisher=}}</ref> |- | [[2006 in video gaming|2006]] || ''[[Rule of Rose]]'' || [[PlayStation 2|PS2]] || [[Punchline (company)|Punchline]] || The mayor of [[Rome]] called for the game to be banned from Italy, saying children "have the right to be shielded from violence".<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news151106ruleofrose| title = Rome mayor wants game banned | author = Bramwell, Tom| publisher = [[Eurogamer]]| date = 2006-11-15| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref> The then [[European Union]] justice and security commissioner wrote an open letter condemning the game for "obscene cruelty and brutality". An Italian magazine, ''[[Panorama (Italian magazine)|Panorama]]'', claimed that in order to win the game players must bury a girl alive, which the game's European publisher disputed.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/505-games-responds-to-rule-of-rose-controversy| title = 505 Games responds to Rule of Rose controversy| author = Gibson, Ellie| publisher = [[Eurogamer|gamesindustry.biz]]| date = 2006-11-17| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref> On the UK release day, the publisher announced that ''Rule of Rose'' would not be published in the UK, despite the game being approved for release by the [[Pan European Game Information]] (PEGI) and Video Standards Council regulatory bodies.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/505-games-cans-rule-of-rose| title = 505 Games cans Rule of Rose| author = Martin, Matt| publisher = [[Eurogamer|gamesindustry.biz]]| date = 2006-11-24| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref> |- | [[2007 in video gaming|2007]] || ''[[BioShock]]'' || [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] , [[PlayStation 3|PS3]] || [[2K Games]] || An article in ''[[The Patriot Ledger]]'', the local paper of developer [[Irrational Games]],<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/130888/bioshock-draws-attention-for-killing-little-girls/| title = BioShock draws attention for 'killing' little girls| author = | publisher = [[GamePro]]| date = 2007-08-24| accessdate = 2008-09-13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210010732/http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/130888/bioshock-draws-attention-for-killing-little-girls/|archivedate=2008-12-10}}</ref> argued that the game is "testing the limits of the ultraviolent gaming genre with a strategy that enables players to kill characters resembling young girls."<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.joystiq.com/2007/08/23/bioshocks-little-sister-killing-gets-mainstream-attention/| title = BioShock's Little Sister killing gets mainstream attention| author = Orland, Kyle| publisher = Joystiq| date = 2007-08-23| accessdate = 2008-09-13}}</ref> The game presents an ethical choice to players, whether to kill 'Little Sisters' for extra abilities or save them and receive less. President of 2K Boston [[Ken Levine (video game designer)|Ken Levine]] defended the game as a piece of art, stating "we want to deal with challenging moral issues and if you want to do that, you have to go to some dark places".<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.kotaku.com.au/games/2007/08/25/killing_little_girls.html| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081210043252/http://www.kotaku.com.au/games/2007/08/25/killing_little_girls.html| archivedate = 2008-12-10| title = Killing Little Girls| author = Fahey, Mike| publisher = Kotaku| date = 2007-08-25| accessdate = 2008-09-13}}</ref> Jack Thompson took issue with advertisements for the game appearing during ''[[WWE SmackDown]]'''s airtime, writing to the [[Federal Trade Commission]] and stating that M-rated games should not be advertised when large numbers of under-17s are watching.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gamepolitics.com/2007/08/19/jack-thompson-shocked-by-bioshock| title = Jack Thompson Shocked by Bioshock TV Ads| author = | publisher = [[GamePolitics.com]]| date = 2007-08-19| accessdate = 2008-09-13| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080829114411/http://gamepolitics.com/2007/08/19/jack-thompson-shocked-by-bioshock| archivedate = 2008-08-29| df = }}</ref> |- |[[2007 in video gaming|2007]] || ''[[Manhunt 2]]'' || [[PlayStation 2|PS2]], [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[Wii]] || [[Rockstar Games]] || ''Manhunt 2'' has been labeled as possibly the most violent video game ever made and is infamous for being one of only four video games to have received an "[[List of AO-rated video games|Adults Only]]" rating due to violence, with the other three being ''[[The Punisher (2005 video game)|The Punisher]]'', ''[[Hatred (video game)|Hatred]]'', and ''[[Agony (2018 video game)|Agony]]''. Further controversy surrounds the Wii version due to the fact that it actually simulates the violence through motion control, dubbing it the name "murder simulator".<ref name="Jesus"/><ref name="Silverman"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Schiesel| first = Seth| title = Under Glare of Scrutiny, a Game Is Toned Down | work = [[The New York Times]]| date = 2007-10-29| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/29/arts/29manh.html| accessdate = 2008-07-23}}</ref> |- | [[2007 in video gaming|2007]] || ''[[Mass Effect (video game)|Mass Effect]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[BioWare]] || Falsely accused by evangelical blogger Kevin McCullough of containing "[[rape]] and [[sodomy]]", which later led to the removal of McCullough's blog entry on [[Townhall.com]]. The game was featured on the [[Fox News Channel]] following the controversy,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gamepolitics.com/2008/01/14/conservative-blogger-claims-mass-effect-offers-customizable-sodomy |title=Blog Archive » Conservative Blogger Claims ''Mass Effect'' Offers "Customizable Sodomy" |publisher=GamePolitics.com |accessdate=2009-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120708133732/http://gamepolitics.com/2008/01/14/conservative-blogger-claims-mass-effect-offers-customizable-sodomy |archivedate=2012-07-08 |df= }}</ref> with host [[Martha MacCallum]], which included the [[headline]] "full graphic sex".<ref name="NYT_flame">{{cite news |first=Seth |last=Schiesel |title=Author Faults a Game, and Gamers Flame Back |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/26/arts/television/26mass.html?_r=3&ref=arts |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2008-01-26 |accessdate=2008-01-26 }}</ref> In actuality, the game's most explicit content is an indirect "[[sideboob]]" shot of a [[humanoid]] alien [[breast]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Mass-Effect-Hits-PC-On-May-6-Alien-Sideboob-Ahoy-9148.html|title=Mass Effect Hits PC On May 6. Alien Sideboob Ahoy!|date=2008-02-07|accessdate=2009-05-30}}</ref> |- | [[2007 in video gaming|2007]] || ''[[Mario Party 8]]'' || [[Wii]] || [[Nintendo]] || Use of the phrase "Turn the train spastic! Make this ticket tragic!" by the character [[List of Mario series characters|Kamek]] caused controversy in the United Kingdom, where the word ''spastic'' is considered offensive. This led to a recall of the game; it was later re-released with the word changed to ''erratic''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/57621-spastic-video-game-is-recalled|title='Spastic' video game is recalled|publisher=Metro.co.uk}}</ref> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Spore (2008 video game)|Spore]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Maxis]]|| ''Spore'''s use and implementation of [[SecuROM]] [[digital rights management]], including the game's activation policies, was subject of widespread criticism and lawsuits; the game was listed as the most pirated game of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/150965/casual_friday_why_spore_wont_work.html|author=PC World|title=Casual Friday: Why ''Spore'' Won't Work|date=2008-09-12|accessdate=2008-09-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13772_3-9939161-52.html?tag=mncol|author1=Daniel Teridman |author2=CNet News |title=Report: Gamers angry at DRM system from EA|date=2008-05-08|accessdate=2008-09-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20080909/BLOG24/809099993|author=HeraldNet | title=Spore DRM: the evolution of a brewing controversy|date=2008-09-09|accessdate=2008-09-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/19/AR2008091900129.html|author1=Staci D. Kramer |author2=Washington Post |title=EA Admits ''Spore'' Launch Botched by DRM; Still, Financial Damage Already Done|date=2008-09-19|accessdate=2008-09-25 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/top-10-most-pirated-games-of-2008-081204/ |title=Top 10 Most Pirated Games of 2008 |publisher=TorrentFreak |date=2008-12-04 |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Muslim Massacre (video game)|Muslim Massacre]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Eric 'Sigvatr' Vaughn || The game's contents and subject have been the subject of strong negative response; a spokesperson for the [[Muslim Council of Britain]] said "The makers of this 'game' and the ISPs (Internet service providers) who are hosting it should be quite ashamed of themselves. Anti-Muslim prejudice is already on the increase and needs to be challenged and not reinforced through tasteless and offensive stunts like this."<ref name="ABC">{{cite web| url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-09-13/muslim-massacre-computer-game-blasted-in-britain/508792| title = 'Muslim Massacre' computer game blasted in Britain| publisher = [[ABC News]]| date = 2008-09-13|accessdate = 2008-09-13}}</ref> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Space Invaders#Other|Invaders!]]'' || || Douglas Edric Stanley || An [[art game]] exhibited at the 2008 [[Games Convention]] in [[Leipzig]]. It represents the [[September 11 attacks]] in the style of ''[[Space Invaders]]''. Players move their bodies to move the cannon and use arm movements to fire.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.abstractmachine.net/blog/30-years-of-invasions/| title = Invaders!| author = Stanley, Douglas Edric| date = August 7, 2008|accessdate = May 31, 2014}}</ref> Like the original ''Space Invaders'', death (game over) is inevitable.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.abstractmachine.net/blog/some-context/| title = Some Context...| author = Stanley, Douglas Edric| date = August 25, 2008|accessdate = May 31, 2014}}</ref> Many people considered it tasteless and inappropriate, and [[Taito]] threatened legal action for unauthorized use of ''Space Invaders'' content.<ref name="Invaders">{{cite web| url = http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=19972| title = Creator of Space Invaders-Based 9/11 Art Piece Pulls Exhibit| publisher = [[Gamasutra]]| author = Remo, Chris| date = August 25, 2008| accessdate = May 31, 2014}}</ref> The creator later pulled the game.<ref name="Invaders"/> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Silent Hill: Homecoming]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[Xbox 360]] || [[Double Helix Games]] || Was banned and refused to get a rating in Australia and Germany for extreme violence and disturbing images which included graphic sexuality, copious blood spray in the game, decapitations, partially dismembered corpses, and numerous scenes of attacks, fights, torture and death.<ref name="IGN">{{cite web| url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/09/30/silent-hill-aussie-ban-update| title = Silent Hill Aussie Ban Update| publisher = [[IGN]]| date = 2008-09-29|accessdate = 2013-01-15}}</ref> The Australian version was subsequently released with the MA15+ rating and censored graphics, while the Japanese release was cancelled altogether.{{cn|date=August 2018}} |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[LittleBigPlanet (PlayStation 3)|LittleBigPlanet]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]] || [[Media Molecule]] || Lyrics from a licensed song, "Tapha Niang", were removed due to fears that Muslims would be offended as it allegedly contained words from the ''[[Quran]]''. This led to controversy about the removal itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2008/10/20/islam_sony/| title = Sony recalls LittleBigPlanet over Quran quote in music | date = 2008-10-20 | accessdate=2008-10-20 | publisher=Machinist: Salon.com | first = Cyrus | last = Farivar}}</ref> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Too Human]]'' || [[Xbox 360]] || [[Silicon Knights]] || The game was revealed to developed using a stolen version of [[Unreal Engine 3]], following a successful counter-suit by [[Epic Games]] (makers of the Unreal Engine), Silicon Knights having initially sued Epic Games for "breach of contract".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.gamedaily.com/industry/feature/?id=16868|title=Yahoo!|website=biz.gamedaily.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=14759|title=Breaking: Silicon Knights Files Lawsuit Against Epic|first=Simon|last=Carless|website=Gamasutra.com}}</ref> In November 2012, the counter-suit were ruled in favor of Epic Games, forcing Silicon Knights to recall and destroy all copies of the game and another Unreal Engine-developed game, ''[[X-Men: Destiny]]'', as well as cancelling other titles that had been planned to use the engine.<ref>[http://wraltechwire.com/business/tech_wire/news/blogpost/11156033/] {{dead link|date=November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2012/11/09/silicon-knights-ordered-to-destroy-unsold-copies-of-all-unreal-engine-games/|title=Silicon Knights ordered to destroy unsold copies of all Unreal Engine games - VG247|date=9 November 2012|website=Vg247.com}}</ref> |- | [[2008 in video gaming|2008]] || ''[[Limbo of the Lost]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Majestic Studios || The game's use of plagiarized assets from other games and movies prompted it's publishers, Tri Synergy, to stop publishing the game.<ref name="gamasutra_limbo">{{cite web | last =Caoili | first =Eric | title =Tri Synergy Discontinues Limbo Of The Lost On Stolen Asset Allegations | website=Gamasutra.com | date =2008-06-12 | url =http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=18999 | accessdate =2008-06-12 }}</ref> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[MadWorld]]'' || [[Wii]] || [[PlatinumGames]] || The game's extreme, over-the-top violence has led to much criticism, and has been described by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' as the "most violent video game ever". Also, the Nintendo Wii has been long-perceived as little more than a "family-friendly" console, and as a result, many parental organizations have condemned the game's release exclusively on the Wii.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1043818/Parents-horrified-violent-video-game-launch-family-friendly-Wii.html |title=Parents horrified as most violent video game ever to launch on 'family friendly' Wii |publisher=Mail Online |date=2008-12-08 |accessdate=2009-02-08 |location=London}}</ref> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[Resident Evil 5]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 4|PS4]], [[Xbox One]], [[Shield Android TV]], [[Shield Portable]], [[Shield Tablet]]|| [[Capcom]] || The game came under controversy for a pre-release trailer that contains scenes of [[racism]],<ref name="re5 imagery">{{cite web| url = http://multiplayerblog.mtv.com/2008/04/10/newsweeks-ngai-croal-on-the-resident-evil-5-trailer-this-imagery-has-a-history/#more-3203| title = Newsweek’s N’Gai Croal On The ‘Resident Evil 5′ Trailer: ‘This Imagery Has A History’| author = John, Tracey| publisher = MTV| date = 2008-04-10| accessdate = 2008-09-12}}</ref> according to ''[[Newsweek]]'' journalist N'Gai Croal in an April 2008 interview. He also stated that organizations and retailers would object to the game and that it would cause controversy on release.<ref name="re5 imagery"/> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[Saw (video game)|Saw]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Konami]] || Several news publishings stated that the game's only purpose was to torture and kill people in violent ways with no sense of restraint or morality. Some editorials called it "depraved and inhumane" and stated that "[[Konami]] should be ashamed".<ref name="Editorial: SAW Game Is Depraved And Inhumane; Konami Should Be Ashamed">{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/SAW-Game-Is-Depraved-And-Inhumane-Konami-Should-Be-Ashamed-18899.html|website=Cinemablend.com|title=Editorial: SAW Game Is Depraved And Inhumane; Konami Should Be Ashamed|date=2009-07-28|accessdate=2009-09-07}}</ref> It was also listed in the "Top ten most controversial games of 2009".<ref name="Most Controversial Games of 2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/features/most-controversial-games-of-2009/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013182425/http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/features/most-controversial-games-of-2009/|archivedate=2009-10-13|publisher=[[GameDaily]]|title=Most Controversial Games of 2009|date=2009-10-08|accessdate=2009-11-02}}</ref> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[Left 4 Dead 2]]'' || [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] ([[Steam (software)|Steam]]) || [[Valve Corporation]] || The cover art in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] had to be altered due to a potentially [[V sign as an insult|offensive hand gesture]] being depicted.<ref name="L4D Logo">{{cite journal|last = Amrich|first = Dan|date = July 2, 2009|title = Only on Xbox 360: Left 4 Dead 2|journal = [[Official Xbox Magazine|Official Xbox Magazine UK]]|issue = 49|page = 43|publisher = Future Publishing}}</ref> The game was banned in [[Australia]] for its excessive violence and gore, but the uncensored version was later rated R18+ in 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.news.com.au/technology/left-4-dead-2-refused-classification-in-australia/story-e6frfro0-1225775873481 | title = Left 4 Dead 2 refused classification in Australia | date = 2009-09-17 | accessdate = 2009-09-17 | first = Andrew | last = Ramadge | publisher = [[News.com.au]]}}</ref> The game's [[New Orleans]] setting so soon after [[Hurricane Katrina]] was considered "a bad call".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.chron.com/gamehacks/2009/07/racism-in-video-games-the-new-norm#more | title = Racism in video games: The new norm? | date = 2009-07-14 | accessdate = 2009-07-30 | first = Willie | last = Jefferson | publisher = [[Houston Chronicle]] | archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/66bIQFACM?url=http://blog.chron.com/gamehacks/2009/07/racism-in-video-games-the-new-norm#more | archive-date = 2012-04-01 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[Fat Princess]]'' || [[PlayStation 3]]<br>[[PlayStation Portable]] || [[Titan Studios]] || Feminists argued that the game concept and title was hostile to women.<ref>Kalning, Kristin. ''[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/25939266/#.U63Ifvl5OSo 'Fat Princess' game stirs up heavy debate]''. Retrieved 27 June 2014.</ref> |- | [[2009 in video gaming|2009]] || ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]], || [[Infinity Ward]] || {{Main|Controversies surrounding Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2}} A optional mission in the game entitled "No Russian" has the player assume control of an undercover [[Central Intelligence Agency]] operative, joining a group of Russian nationalist terrorists who perpetrate an airport massacre. The player is given the option to skip it at any point,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2009/10/28/new-modern-warfare-airport-murder-simulator-2-video-game-glorif/|title=New Modern Warfare: Airport Murder Simulator 2 video game glorifies terrorism|last=Kietzmann|first=Ludwig|date=2009-10-28|website=Joystiq.com|accessdate=2009-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5392161/modern-warfare-2-features-skippable-scene-of-atrocities|title=Modern Warfare 2 Features Skippable Scene of Atrocities - Modern warfare 2 - Kotaku|last=Crecente|first=Brian|date=2009-10-28|website=Feeds.gawker.com|accessdate=2009-11-08}}</ref> and a warning before the campaign also notifies players of the disturbing material. The game was discussed briefly in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] after the issue was brought to the attention of MP [[Keith Vaz]], a longtime opponent of violence in video games, with fellow [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] politician [[Tom Watson (Labour politician)|Tom Watson]] arguing that the level was "no worse than scenes in many films and books" and criticising Vaz for "collaborating with the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' to create moral panic over the use of video games".<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Commons, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200809/cmhansrd/cm091109/debtext/91109-0002.htm |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 09 Nov 2009 (pt 0002) |date=2009-11-09 |accessdate=2009-11-15}}</ref> The mission was made optional before release<ref>{{cite web|first=Natalie|last=Shoemaker |url=http://www.geek.com/articles/games/the-most-controversial-moments-in-call-of-duty-history-20120511/ |title=The most controversial moments in Call of Duty history |publisher=Geek.com |date=2012-03-11 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> and removed from the game entirely.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neoseeker.com/forums/41612/t1448614-russians-ban-modern-warfare-2-console-versions-for-no-russian-mission/ |title=Russians ban Modern Warfare 2 console versions for 'No Russian' mission - Neoseeker Forums |publisher=Neoseeker.com |accessdate=2009-11-16}}</ref>
Activision later removed the Favela multiplayer map from ''Modern Warfare 2'' following complaints from Muslim gamers, which shows picture frames on the second floor bathroom of one building within Favela. When viewed through a scoped weapon, the frames contain a quote from Muhammad that translates to "Allah is beautiful and He loves beauty", according to ''Islam Today''. One of the paintings is located directly above a toilet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/10/08/modern-warfare-2-map-removed-following-controversy |title=Modern Warfare 2 Map Removed Following Controversy |website=IGN.com |date=2012-10-08 }}</ref> |- | [[2010 in video gaming|2010]] || ''[[Medal of Honor (2010 video game)|Medal of Honor]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Danger Close Games]], [[EA Digital Illusions CE]] || The multiplayer mode created controversy when it was revealed that players could play as the Taliban.<ref name="aolnews.com">[http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/new-video-game-will-let-you-play-as-the-taliban/19588413 New Video Game Will Let You Play as the Taliban] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901191803/http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/new-video-game-will-let-you-play-as-the-taliban/19588413 |date=2010-09-01 }}, [[AOL News]], August 13, 2010</ref> The developers responded by stating the reality of the game necessitated it, but due to pressure from various military officials and veterans organizations, the word Taliban was removed from the multiplayer part of the game in which players would directly play as the Taliban, instead replaced with the term "Opposing Force." However, even in light of this change, the game is still not to be sold on military bases. The AAFES Commander Maj. Gen. Bruce Casella said, "Out of respect to those touched by the ongoing, real-life events presented as a game, Exchanges will not be carrying this product." He continued, "I expect the military families who are authorized to shop the Exchange are aware, and understanding, of the decision not to carry this particular offering."<ref>{{cite web |last=Goodrich |first=Greg |url=http://www.medalofhonor.com/blog/2010/10/multiplayer-change |title=Multiplayer Change | Medal of Honor — Coming October 12, 2010 |publisher=Medal of Honor |date=2010-10-01 |accessdate=2010-10-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101004113409/http://www.medalofhonor.com/blog/2010/10/multiplayer-change |archive-date=October 4, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sliwinski |first=Alexander |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/10/05/military-stores-wont-carry-medal-of-honor-despite-taliban-cha/ |title=Military stores won't carry Medal of Honor despite 'Taliban' change |website=Joystiq.com |date=2010-10-05 |accessdate=2010-10-14}}</ref> |- | [[2010 in video gaming|2010]] || ''[[Six Days in Fallujah]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Atomic Games]] || The game was opposed by both the public and critics alike for "glamorizing" and "glossing over" the real-life [[Second Battle of Fallujah]]. This caused the former publisher, [[Konami]], to stop publishing it.<ref name="dailymail">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1168235/Iraq-War-video-game-branded-crass-insensitive-father-Red-Cap-killed-action.html |title=Iraq War video game branded 'crass and insensitive' by father of Red Cap killed in action |website=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2011-10-21 |location=London}}</ref> |- | [[2011 in video gaming|2011]] || ''[[Bulletstorm]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Electronic Arts]] || [[Fox News Channel]] called out the title as the "Worst Video Game in the World" due to the extreme amount of violence; claims made in the original article were dispelled by video game journalists including [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun|Rock Paper Shotgun]], but Fox News continues to assert the game as too violent.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2011/02/20/fox-news-blogger-continues-to-beat-the-bulletstorm-drum.aspx | title = Fox News Blogger Continues To Beat The Bulletstorm Drum | first = Jeff | last = Cork | date = 2011-02-20 | accessdate = 2011-02-21 | work = [[Game Informer]] }}</ref> |- | [[2011 in video gaming|2011]] || ''[[Portal 2]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Valve Corporation]] || CBS News has deemed the game offensive to adopted children because Wheatley insults the protagonist by saying "Fatty fatty no parents". The daughter of the parents who reported this is in fact, adopted.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/slow-news-day-leads-to-portal-2-adoption-controversy/ |title=Slow news day leads to Portal 2 adoption "controversy" |last1=Goulter |first1=Tom |last2= |first2= |date=May 19, 2011 |work=[[GamesRadar]] |accessdate=May 31, 2013}}</ref> |- | [[2011 in video gaming|2011]] || ''[[Call of Juarez: The Cartel]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Ubisoft]] || Residents of [[Ciudad Juárez]] and Mexico protested the announcement of the game, believing it to highlight the [[Juárez Cartel]], who are believed responsible for over 3000 homicides in the city in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url =https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-usa-mexico-game-idUSTRE71G6B020110217?feedType=RSS&feedName=domesticNews | title = Cartel video game riles U.S.-Mexico border residents | first = Julian | last = Cardona | first2 = Alejandro | last2 = Martinez-Cabrera | publisher = Reuters | date = 2011-02-17 | accessdate = 2011-02-21 }}</ref> |- | [[2011 in video gaming|2011]] || ''[[Dead Island]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Deep Silver]] || After a development build of the game was released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] by mistake, it was revealed that the skill 'Gender Wars' (which the character Purna uses) was called 'FeministWhorePurna' within the game's code. Developer [[Deep Silver]] apologised and released a patch for the game to replace the offensive name.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-09-08-dead-island-developer-techland-disturbed-by-feminist-whore-skill | title = Dead Island Developer Techland Disturbed by Feminist Whore Skill | first = Robert | last = Purchese | publisher = Eurogamer | date = 2011-07-08 | accessdate = 2013-04-19 }}</ref> |- | [[2011 in video gaming|2011]] || ''[[Star Citizen]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Cloud Imperium Games]] || A [[crowdfunding|crowdfunded]] game, ''Star Citizen'' have attracted criticism for the constant, frequent delays of the game's release deadlines, while continuing to raise additional funds,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/fans-dropped-77m-guys-buggy-half-built-game/|title=Fans Have Dropped $77M on This Guy’s Buggy, Half-Built Game|last=Baker|first=Chris|work=WIRED|access-date=May 2, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tentonhammer.com/articles/stop-funding-star-citizen|title=Stop Funding Star Citizen|access-date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> with the developers facing legal actions from [[Derek Smart]]<ref name="Chalk 2015">{{cite web | last=Chalk | first=Andy | title=Derek Smart threatens legal action against Cloud Imperium Games over Star Citizen | website=PC Gamer | date=2015-08-24 | url=http://www.pcgamer.com/derek-smart-threatens-legal-action-against-cloud-imperium-games-over-star-citizen/ | access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> and [[CryTek]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-12-14-the-star-citizen-makers-are-being-sued-by-crytek|title=The Star Citizen makers are being sued by Crytek|website=Eurogamer}}</ref> |- | [[2012 in video gaming|2012]] || ''[[Counter-Strike: Global Offensive]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] ([[Steam (software)|Steam]])|| [[Valve Corporation]] || In 2016, the game came under fire on the grounds of several players using third party betting through the use of [[skin gambling]], where players sell in-game cosmetics for real currency. This led to concerns of potential underage players participating in skin gambling, which may lead to future gambling addictions, as well as the potential of [[match fixing]] within the game's competitive scene (see [[iBuyPower and NetcodeGuides match fixing scandal]]). Valve has since ordered a cease and desist against many ''Counter-Strike'' gambling websites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/7/11/12129136/counter-strike-global-offensive-cs-go-skins-explainer|title=How do Counter-Strike: Global Offensive skins work?|website=Polygon.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esportsbettingreport.com/valve-skin-betting-cease-desist/|title=23 Skin Gambling Sites Targeted With Cease And Desist By Valve|date=20 July 2016|website=Esportswbettingreport.com}}</ref> |- | [[2012 in video gaming|2012]] || ''[[Medal of Honor: Warfighter]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Danger Close Games]] || Seven members of Naval Special Warfare Development Group (DEVGRU) who worked as consultants for the game were disciplined for releasing classified information to the game's creators.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18563_162-57547417/7-navy-seals-disciplined-for-role-with-video-game/ |title=7 Navy SEALs disciplined for role with video game| publisher=CBS News |date=8 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-11| last=Martin| first=David }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last=Dozier| first=Kimberly| title=Pentagon cracks down on SEALs troops who spill secrets about their missions for profit| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/defense-official-7-navy-seals-punished-for-allegedly-revealing-classified-info-to-video-maker/2012/11/08/7f3b402e-2a0a-11e2-aaa5-ac786110c486_story.html| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109221938/http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/defense-official-7-navy-seals-punished-for-allegedly-revealing-classified-info-to-video-maker/2012/11/08/7f3b402e-2a0a-11e2-aaa5-ac786110c486_story.html| archive-date=2012-11-09| agency=Associated Press| publisher=AP| accessdate=2012-11-09| deadurl=yes}}</ref> |- | [[2012 in video gaming|2012]] || ''[[Street Fighter X Tekken]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[iOS]], [[PlayStation Vita]] || [[Capcom]], [[Dimps]] || It was revealed that the game's [[downloadable content|downloadable characters]] were already on the disc in a ready-to-unlock form, leading to heavy criticism.<ref name="sfxt-playuk">{{cite web|url=http://www.play-mag.co.uk/latest-playstation-news/capcom-includes-paid-dlc-on-the-disc-hilariously/|title=Capcom Includes Paid DLC On The Disc, Hilariously|author=Dransfield, Ian|publisher=Play|accessdate=March 16, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/features/on-disc-dlc-outrage-is-off-the-mark-6366340/|title=On-Disc DLC Outrage Is Off the Mark|author=Sinclair, Brendan|date=March 16, 2012|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=March 16, 2012}}</ref> |- | [[2012 in video gaming|2012]] || ''[[Persona 4 Arena]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]] || [[Atlus]], [[Arc System Works]] || The PlayStation 3 version of the game includes a regional lockout, allowing the game to be played only if the game's region matches the console region, despite the fact that PlayStation 3 games are normally region-free, leading to a massive fan outrage.<ref name="egmnow.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/persona-4-arena-to-be-first-ever-region-locked-ps3-release/|title=Persona 4 Arenea to be first region locked PS3 release|accessdate=August 30, 2012|publisher=EGMNow}}</ref><ref name="siliconera_region">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/07/07/atlus-addresses-persona-4-arena-region-locking|title=Atlus Addresses Persona 4 Arena Region-Locking|publisher=IGN|date=July 6, 2012|author=Dyer, Mitch|accessdate=August 7, 2012}}</ref> The game's sequel, ''[[Persona 4 Arena Ultimax]]'' however was region-free.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sirani|first1=Jordan|title=Persona 4 Arena Ultimax is Region-Free|url=http://ca.ign.com/articles/2014/07/10/persona-4-arena-ultimax-is-region-free|website=[[IGN]]|accessdate=2016-11-03}}</ref> |- | [[2012 in video gaming|2012]] || ''[[Mass Effect 3]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[Wii U]] || [[BioWare]] || While critically acclaimed overall, the ending of ''Mass Effect 3'' was highly criticized as, among other issues, rendered all the decisions players had made in the trilogy, carried over through save files, moot, in contrast to marketing material BioWare had put forth for the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gamehunters/post/2012/03/bioware-no-decision-yet-on-mass-effect-3-ending/1#.T2dolB7HZaQ|title=BioWare: No decision yet on 'Mass Effect 3' ending|last=Molina|first=Brett|date=March 19, 2012|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=March 19, 2012}}</ref> Due to a large reaction from the player base, BioWare released free [[downloadable content]] that provided a more cinematic ending sequence that addressed some of these concerns.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2012/03/22/mass-effect-3-makers-to-rewrite-soul-crushing-ending-for-furious-fans/|title='Mass Effect 3' makers to rewrite 'soul-crushing' ending for furious fans|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=March 22, 2012}}</ref> |- | [[2013 in video gaming|2013]] || ''[[Payday 2]]'' || [[PlayStation 4|PS4]], [[Xbox One]], [[Personal computer|PC]], [[Nintendo Switch]] || [[Overkill Software]] || ''Payday 2'', while having featured a large array of downloadable content, had been claimed by its developers would never include microtransactions. However, a major game update released in October 2015 included rewards that required the player to use real-world money to purchase keys to unlock, and with rewards that may not be usable if the player did not buy certain pieces of downloadable content. Fans of the game reacted negatively to the change.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-10-16-payday-2-community-erupts-in-anger-at-addition-of-stat-changing-microtransactions | title = PayDay 2 community erupts in anger at addition of stat-changing microtransactions | publisher = [[Eurogamer]] | date = October 16, 2015 | accessdate = October 19, 2015 | first = Tom | last = Philips }}</ref> In May 2016, Overkill was able to acquire full rights to the ''Payday'' series, and among other announcements relating to the series, announced they would remove the microtransactions from ''Payday 2''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2016/05/30/payday-franchise-rights-back-to-overkill-microtransactions-removed-more/ | title = Payday franchise rights back to Overkill, microtransactions removed, more | first = Sherif | last = Saed | date = May 30, 2016 | accessdate = May 31, 2016 | work = [[VG247]] }}</ref> |- | [[2013 in video gaming|2013]] || ''[[Tomb Raider (2013 video game)|Tomb Raider]]'' || [[PlayStation 3|PS3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Crystal Dynamics]] || During an interview with Kotaku, executive producer Ron Rosenberg stated that one scene in the game depicts [[Lara Croft]] about to be [[sexually assaulted]] by a scavenger. She is forced to fight back and kill him in return. Prior to the game's release, this quickly led to controversy concerning the possible "attempted rape" sequence. Studio manager Darrell Gallagher later denied this, stating that one of "the character defining moments for Lara in the game, which has incorrectly been referred to as an 'attempted rape' scene is the content we showed" where "Lara is forced to kill another human for the first time. In this particular selection, while there is a threatening undertone in the sequence and surrounding drama, it never goes any further than the scenes that we have already shown publicly. Sexual assault of any kind is categorically not a theme that we cover in this game."<ref name="forbes_controversy">{{cite news|last=Griffiths|first=Daniel Nye|title=That Was Quick: Crystal Dynamics Responds On Tomb Raider Controversy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielnyegriffiths/2012/06/13/crystal-dynamics-tomb-raider/|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=14 June 2012|date=13 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="kotaku_controversy">{{cite web|last=Schreier|first=Jason|title=Tomb Raider Creators Are No Longer Referring to Game’s Attempted ‘Rape’ Scene As an Attempted Rape Scene|url=http://kotaku.com/5918193/tomb-raider-creators-are-no-longer-referring-to-games-attempted-rape-scene-as-an-attempted-rape-scene|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=14 June 2012|date=13 June 2012}}</ref> |- | [[2013 in video gaming|2013]] || ''[[Saints Row IV]]'' || [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Volition (company)|Volition]] || Despite changes in the [[Australian Classification Board]] to adopt rules to use the R18+ rating for video games in January 2013, ''Saints Row IV'' was the first video game under these new rules to be denied classification, due to the presence of drug use and an in-game alien anal probe weapon.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/25/4464820/saints-row-4-refused-classification-in-australia-due-to-alien | title = Saints Row 4 refused classification in Australia due to 'alien narcotics' and an 'Alien Anal Probe' | first = Jenna | last = Pitcher | date = 25 June 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2013 | publisher = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> Volition eliminated these elements from the game to obtain a MA15+ rating by removing the mission these elements were used in,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2013/8/2/4581454/censored-saints-row-4-receives-ma15-rating-in-australia | title = Censored Saints Row 4 receives MA15+ rating in Australia | first = Jenna | last = Pitcher | date = 2 August 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2013 | publisher = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> rendering the game's co-operative mode incompatible with versions from other countries.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2013/8/5/4589676/saints-row-4-in-australia-not-compatible-for-co-op-play-in-other | title = Saints Row 4 in Australia barred from international co-op (update) | first = Jenna | last = Pitcher | date = 5 August 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2013 | publisher = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> |- | [[2013 in video gaming|2013]] || ''[[The Stanley Parable]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Galactic Cafe || An in-game instructional video called "Choice" contained an image of a white man lighting a black child on fire.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/128976-The-Stanley-Parable-Maker-Promises-to-Change-Racist-Image |title = The Stanley Parable Maker Promises to Change "Racist" Image|last = Chalk |first = Andy |publisher = [[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]] |date = 23 October 2013 |accessdate= 22 December 2013 }}</ref> |- | [[2014 in video gaming|2014]] || ''[[South Park: The Stick of Truth]]'' || [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Personal computer|PC]] || [[Obsidian Entertainment]],<br>[[South Park Digital Studios]] || The game was censored (by [[Ubisoft]]'s decision) in Europe and Australia due to its depiction of an anal probing by aliens and the player-character performing an abortion. In their place, the game displays a still image of a statue holding its face in its hand, with an explicit description of events depicted in the scene. The German version was specifically censored because of the use of Nazi- and Hitler-related imagery, including swastikas and Nazi salutes, which in that country are outlawed outside of the context of "art or science, research or teaching"<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/englisch_stgb/englisch_stgb.html#p0868 |title = Strafgesetzbuch, sections 86, 86a}}</ref>. The PC version remains completely uncut in Europe.<ref>{{cite news|first=Toby |last=Moses |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/05/south-park-stick-of-truth-game-censored-europe |title=Why has the South Park: Stick of Truth game been censored in Europe? |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |work=[[theguardian.com]]|date=March 5, 2014 |accessdate=April 6, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311104237/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/05/south-park-stick-of-truth-game-censored-europe |archivedate=March 11, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref> |- | [[2015 in video gaming|2015]] || ''[[Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number]]'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Dennaton Games || The sequel, like the first ''[[Hotline Miami]]'', incorporates a large amount of violence as the player sets to kill off agents of the local mafia, but a preview build for the sequel includes a scene that is set up where the player's character then appears to rape a female antagonist, though this is later presented in the context of being part of a staged movie scene. Journalists felt that even though the game made it clear of the scene's setup, the inclusion of this scene went too far in taste levels.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.computerandvideogames.com/424642/anger-over-rape-scene-in-hotline-miami-2/ | title= Anger over 'rape scene' in Hotline Miami 2 | first = Rob | last = Crossley | date = 15 August 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2013 | publisher = [[Computer and Video Games]]}}</ref> Despite some changes and assurances made by the developer, the scene in the game caused the [[Australian Classification Board]] to refuse to classify the game, effectively preventing legal sale of the title in that country.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/01/hotline-miami-2-blocked-from-sale-in-australia-over-implied-rape-scene/ | title = Hotline Miami 2 blocked from sale in Australia over implied rape scene | first = Kyle | last = Orland | date = January 15, 2015 | accessdate = January 16, 2015 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] }}</ref> |- | [[2015 in video gaming|2015]] || ''[[Hatred (video game)|Hatred]] '' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Destructive Creations || A game about a suicidal mass murderer, in which the primary mechanic is about shooting innocent civilians in the murderer's fit of rage. The CEO behind ''Hatred'' has been accused of having neo-Nazi, anti-Islamic affiliations due to [[Facebook like button|liking]] some pages on [[Facebook]] related to such beliefs.<ref name="polygon greenlight">{{cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/20/7020277/ceo-behind-hatred-neo-nazi-anti-islamic-responds | title = Change title| first= Charlie| last = Hall | date = 2014-08-20| accessdate = 2015-01-08 | publisher = [[Polygon]] }}</ref> The title has been highly controversial, and when the developers attempted to place it on the [[Steam (software)|Steam]] Greenlight service, it was pulled by Valve due to the game's content; however, it has been brought back onto Greenlight by [[Gabe Newell]], and later apologized for the removal.<ref name="eurogamer greenlight">{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-12-15-controversial-mass-murdering-game-hatred-appears-on-steam-greenlight | title = Controversial mass murdering game Hatred appears on Steam Greenlight | first= Jeffrey | last = Matulef | date = 2014-12-15 | accessdate = 2014-12-16 | publisher = [[Eurogamer]] }}</ref> The game was rated "Adults Only" (AO) by the [[ESRB]], which prevents retail sales and its release on consoles and would likely prevent its sale on digital storefronts for personal computers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hatred given Adults Only rating in US and Canada|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/1/16/7557639/hatred-esrb-ao-rating|website=Polygon|accessdate=January 16, 2015 | date = January 16, 2015}}</ref> |- | [[2015 in video gaming|2015]] || ''Playing History 2: Slave Trade'' || [[Personal computer|PC]] || Serious Games || The game was created by Serious Games as an [[edutainment]] title to teach the user about [[history of slavery|slave trading]]. One game mode in the title was called "Slave Tetris", with the goal to try to fit as many African slaves on a boat, using gameplay similar to ''[[Tetris]]''; the developer had intended to show how inhumane the slave traders were and how such trade boats were packed to capacity, stating "it really gets people to think about just how absurd and cruel it is". When the mode was discovered by a wider audience due to discounted sales of the game and [[Let's Play (video gaming)|Let's Play]] broadcasts of it, many critics expressed distaste for the mode, considering it to be highly insensitive. The developer pulled the mode from the game following this outrage.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/09/after-outcry-edutainment-game-removes-slave-tetris-mode/ | title = After outcry, "edutainment" game removes slave-Tetris mode | first = Sam | last = Machkovech | date = 2015-09-03 | accessdate = 2015-09-04 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] }}</ref> |- | [[2015 in video gaming|2015]] || ''[[Survival Island 3]]'' || [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] || NIL Entertainment || A first-person action game in which the [[White people|fair-skinned]] player-character has to fight and kill [[Indigenous Australians]] as well as [[Australian fauna]]. After a [[Change.org]] petition, the game was pulled from the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]] and [[Google Play]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Demands for 'racist' Survival Island 3 game to be removed from app stores|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-16/demands-for-'racist'-survival-island-3-game-to-be-taken-down/7092782|website = ABC News|access-date = 2016-01-16|language = en-AU}}</ref> |- | [[2015 in video gaming|2015]] || ''[[Pakistan Army Retribution]]'' || [[Android (operating system)|Android]] || || A first-person shooter game, based upon the [[2014 Peshawar school massacre]]. Developed as part of the Peaceful Pakistan peace campaign, the game allowed the player to control a soldier during the attack and kill Taliban terrorists. After a negative review on the website of newspaper ''[[DAWN (newspaper)|DAWN]]'', calling the game to be of "poor taste",<ref name="DAWN">{{cite web|last1=Rahool|first1=Munir|title=Review: This Army Public School attack game fails on every front|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1232492|website=[[DAWN (newspaper)|DAWN]]|publisher= |accessdate=2016-02-22|date= 2015-02-11}}</ref> other people also outed their criticism.<ref name="ABC2">{{cite web|last1=|first1=|title=Pakistan removes Taliban school massacre video game after social media uproar|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-19/pakistan-removes-school-massacre-video-game-after-uproar/7097098|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]|publisher= |accessdate=2016-02-22|date= 2015-01-18}}</ref> The game was subsequently pulled from the Google Play Store in January 2016. |- | [[2016 in video gaming|2016]] || ''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]]'' || [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] || [[Blizzard Entertainment]] || A team-based multiplayer shooter includes a number of unique characters, and matches concluded with the winning character doing one of several possible victory poses that can be selected by the player. Some players found that the victory pose for one character, a young woman named [[Tracer (Overwatch)|Tracer]] who is also shown on the game's cover art, was overtly sexual and reduced the character to a "bland female sex symbol".<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2016/03/29/overwatch-blizzard-removes-sexualized-tracer-win-pose-following-fan-complaint/ | title = Overwatch – Blizzard removes "sexualized" Tracer win pose following fan complaint |first = Sherif | last = Saed |date = 2016-03-29 | accessdate = 2016-04-06 | work = [[VG247]] }}</ref> Blizzard removed the offending pose, replacing it with a [[pin-up model]]-inspired pose.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2016/04/06/overwatchs-tracer-butt-pose-replaced/ | title = Overwatch’s Tracer butt pose replaced with cheesecake pin-up stance | date = 2016-04-06 | accessdate = 2016-04-06 | first = Sherif | last = Saed | work = [[VG247]] }}</ref> |- | [[2016 in video gaming|2016]] || ''[[Street Fighter V]]'' || [[PlayStation 4]], [[Microsoft Windows]] || [[Capcom]], [[Dimps]] || An update for the PC version of the game released in September 2016 included a [[device driver]] named [[Capcom.sys]], as a part of the game's anti-cheat measures, which was seen by players and security analysts as a [[rootkit]]. Capcom has since provided a rollback.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/capcom-promises-street-fighter-5-rollback-after-rootkit-discovered-in-the-latest-update/ | title = Capcom promises Street Fighter 5 rollback after "rootkit" discovered in the latest update | work = [[PC Gamer]] | date= 2016-09-23 | accessdate = 2016-12-14 | first = Andy | last = Chalk }}</ref> In 2017, an update which added [[M. Bison]]'s classic [[Street Fighter II]] stage was taken down after fans noticed Islamic chants in what was actually a Buddhist temple.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frank|first1=Allegra|title=Street Fighter 5 players notice Islamic chants in new Buddhist temple stage|url=http://www.polygon.com/2017/4/26/15439980/street-fighter-5-thailand-stage-music-islamic-chant|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> |- | [[2016 in video gaming|2016]] || ''[[Baldur's Gate: Siege of Dragonspear]]'' || [[Microsoft Windows]] || [[Beamdog]] || ''Siege of Dragonspear'' is an expansion atop Beamdog's ''[[Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition]]'', itself a remastering of the original 1998 game, providing a narrative to explain events between ''[[Baldur's Gate]]'' and [[Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn|its sequel]]. Though the game was criticized by players on its release due to a number of software bugs, a controversy arose at what was perceived as a forced political agenda by the developers, in particular the inclusion of a [[transgender]] character.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-05-new-baldurs-gate-expansion-siege-of-dragonspear-off-to-a-rough-start | title = New Baldur's Gate expansion Siege of Dragonspear off to a rough start | work = [[Eurogamer]] | date= 2016-04-05 | accessdate = 2016-04-05 | first = Robert | last = Purchase }}</ref> |- | [[2016 in video gaming|2016]] || ''[[Pokémon Go]]'' || [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] || [[Niantic, Inc.]], [[Nintendo]] || ''Pokémon Go'' gained significant controversy after the game allegedly inspired criminals to commit robberies using the augmented reality feature. [[Cable News Network|CNN]] reported that the geolocation feature was used for robbers to find and capture victims.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lindh|first1=Clara|title=What Pokémon GO has to do with armed robbery and a dead body|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/11/tech/pokemon-go-crazy-events/|accessdate=11 July 2016|work=CNN|publisher=CNN|date=11 July 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2016 in video gaming|2016]] | ''[[Persona 5]]'' | [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]] | [[Atlus]] | Atlus spoiler policy for the game, including the disabling of native streaming of the game, as well as threatening takedowns of users posting videos of the game's endgame, were highly criticized by the game's fans.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} |- | [[2017 in video gaming|2017]] | ''Fight of Gods'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] | PQube | ''Fight of Gods'' was designed as a satirical fighting game between various religious and mythical god or god-like figures. In September 2017, after [[Jesus]] was added as a playable character, the government of Malaysia considered the game "blasphemous", demanded [[Valve Corporation|Valve]] remove the game from [[Steam (software)|Steam]], and had its [[Internet service providers|ISP]]s temporarily block the country's access to Steam. Valve eventually blocked sale of the game in Malaysia, allowing the service to be restored in the country.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2017/09/08/malaysian-government-block-their-citizens-from-accessing-steam-over-fighting-game-where-jesus-can-fight-buddha/ | title = Malaysian Government block their citizens from accessing Steam over fighting game where Jesus can fight Buddha | first = Alex | last = Donaldson | date = September 8, 2017 | accessdate = September 8, 2017 | work =[[VG247]] }}</ref><Ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamesn.com/fight-of-gods/steam-blocked-malaysia-fight-of-gods | title = Steam is back in Malaysia, but Fight of Gods is no longer available there | first = Ali | last = Jones | date = September 8, 2017 | accessdate= September 8, 2017 | work = [[PCGamesN]] }}</ref> |- | [[2017 in video gaming|2017]] | ''[[Star Wars Battlefront II (2017 video game)|Star Wars Battlefront II]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] | [[Electronic Arts]] | In November 2017, ''Battlefront II'' received unfavorable critical attention when its [[loot box]] monetization scheme during its open beta period was revealed, which many felt was a "pay-to-win" scheme since some loot box rewards directly influenced multiplayer gameplay. Electronic Arts revisited the loot box approach prior to launch to address those concerns.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2017/10/13/after-beta-controversy-dice-has-better-clarified-the-loot-crate-system-in-the-final-version-of-star-wars-battlefront-2/ | title = After beta controversy, DICE has better clarified the ‘loot crate’ and progression systems in Star Wars Battlefront 2 | first = James | last = O'Conner | date = October 13, 2017 | accessdate = October 13, 2017 | work = [[VG247]] }}</ref> Just before the game's full launch, it was revealed that many of the playable heroes in the game would be locked until the player had earned enough in-game credits over time, or spent money on microtransactions to unlock them faster, raising further player criticism. Electronic Arts attempted to justify the change on the game's subforum at [[Reddit]] but it was met with outrage, making that comment the most down-voted Reddit post of all time.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/13/ea-star-wars-game-is-so-unpopular-the-developer-is-getting-threats.html | title = EA's new Star Wars game is so unpopular a developer is apparently getting death threats | first = Sara | last = Salinis | date = November 13, 2017 | accessdate = November 13, 2017 | work = [[CNBC]] }}</ref> Hours before the game's release, EA temporarily disabled all microtransactions for the game to review concerns by players and rework these in-currency systems after launch.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.usgamer.net/articles/battlefront-kill-loot-boxes-ea | title = Report: EA to Kill Star Wars Battlefront 2's Monetized Loot Box Progression | first = matt | last = Kim | date = November 16, 2017 | accessdate = November 16, 2017 | work = [[US Gamer]]}}</ref> |- | [[2018 in video gaming|2018]] | ''[[Standoff (video game)]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] | Revived Games | Originally titled ''Active Shooter'', the game was developed by Revived Games and is to be published by Acid Games in June 2018 on [[Steam (software)|Steam]]. The game presented a first-person shooter based on a fictional school shooting scenario, with the game's description stating that the player can chose to be the SWAT team member to take down the suspects, or the students firing on the school. The game, which appeared on Steam shortly following the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]] in February 2018, came under criticism from students, parents, and politicians, directing concern towards the developers, publisher, and Valve for trying to profit off an emotional distressing situation.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/28/us/active-shooter-video-game-steam-valve-trnd/index.html?no-st=1527630340 | title = Parents of Parkland victims are outraged about a new video game that would let players shoot up a school | date = May 28, 2018 | accessdate = May 29, 2018 | work = [[CNN]] | first = Andrea | last = Diaz }}</ref> Before the game could be released, Valve pulled the game and the developer from Steam, citing prior issues with "asset reuse" games by the developer and manipulation of Steam reviews.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/evkp3a/active-shooter-removed-from-steam-by-valve | title= Valve Has Removed a School Shooting Simulator From Steam, Calling the Developer a 'Troll' | first = Matthew| last = Gault | date =May 29, 2018 | accessdate = May 29, 2018 | work = [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] }}</ref> |- | [[2018 in video gaming|2018]] | ''[[Agony (2018 video game)|Agony]]'' | [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation 4|PS4]], [[Xbox One]], [[Nintendo Switch]] | Madmind Studio | A dark fantasy survival horror video game that puts players into the perspective of a tormented soul within the depths of Hell devoid of any memories about his/her past. The special ability to control people on their path, and possess weak-minded demons, gives players the necessary measures to survive in the extreme conditions they are in.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playway.com/10004-games/519-agony|title=Playway - Agony|publisher=Playway.com}}</ref> ''Agony'' is infamous for being one of only four games to have received the "Adults Only" rating from ESRB due to violence and other extreme graphic content (including gay and lesbian sex scenes and genital physics), following ''[[The Punisher (2005 video game)|The Punisher]]'', ''[[Manhunt 2]]'', and ''[[Hatred (video game)|Hatred]]''. The game was rerated "Mature" after the developers agreed to tone down the violence, which also led to [[Pan European Game Information|PEGI]] rating the game 18. A planned "Adults Only" unrated patch for PC was later dropped due to "legal issues".<ref name="PCGamerpatch">{{cite web | url=https://www.pcgamer.com/hellish-horror-game-agony-will-be-slightly-toned-down-uncensored-patch-plan-dropped/ | title=Hellish horror game Agony will be slightly toned down, 'uncensored' patch plan dropped | publisher=PC Gamer | date=May 28, 2018 | accessdate=May 28, 2018 | author=Chalk, Andy}}</ref> However, on June 6, 2018, the developers said they were "talking with [[Steam (software)|Steam]] representatives" about offering Agony Unrated as "a separate title produced and published by Madmind Studio and without the involvement of any publishers." For those who already own the original game, this version will be either free DLC or a separate purchase at 99% off, which currently is the highest possible discount on Steam's platform.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://steamcommunity.com/games/487720/announcements/detail/1648761723383113903|title=Agony :: Agony Unrated!|date=2018-06-06|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}}</ref> After announcing the financial problems of the company and canceling the Unrated version of the game, the basic game docked on August 1, 2018, with a considerable amount of updates on the platforms on which it debuted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/playway/agony/updates|title=Agony|website=Kickstarter|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> |- |[[2018 in video gaming|2018]] |''[[Bolsomito 2K18]]'' |[[Personal computer|PC]] |BS Studios |''Bolsomito 2K18'', a brawler game where the player fights "the evils of communism" and "the growing corruption and inversion of values that plages [sic] his society", according to its description, while in game, this is represented as attacking women, minorities, and LGBTQ persons. The game was released on Steam two days prior to the October [[Brazilian general election, 2018|2018 Brazilian general election]], where one of the candidates in the election was [[Jair Bolsonaro]], which served as inspiration for the game's name. Bolsonaro was considered a [[far right]] candidate in the election and led after the first round of voting. The Brazilian Public Ministry of the Federal District and Territories has opened an investigation on both Valve and BS Studios, stating the that game and its close release to the elections "clearly intends to harm [the] Presidency of the Republic and thereby embarrass the 2018 elections" and "cause collective moral damages to the movements social, gays and feminists".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/328535/Valve_under_investigation_by_Brazilian_government_over_violent_political_game.php | title = Valve under investigation by Brazilian government over violent political game | first = Emma | last = Kidwell | date = October 12, 2018 | accessdate = October 12, 2018 | work = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-10-11-valve-under-investigation-by-brazilian-government-for-selling-game-inciting-violence-against-election-candidates | title = Valve investigated by Brazilian government over game which incites violence against election candidates | first = Emma | last = Kent | date = October 11, 2018 | accessdate = October 12, 2018 | work = [[Eurogamer]] }}</ref> |- |[[2018 in video gaming|2018]] |''[[Diablo Immortal]]'' |iOS/Android |[[Blizzard Entertainment]] |''Diablo Immortal'', a [[mobile game]] port was announced at the 2018 [[Blizzcon]] event, with Blizzard having teased something ''Diablo'' related in the weeks prior. Upon the announcement, fans at the event booed the presentation, and other fans took to social media to express discontentment with the announcement. Complaints from games ranged from concern that ''Diablo Immortal'' was a re-skin of a previous game developed by [[NetEase]] (who are also developing ''Immortall''), to issues related to Blizzard long-time fans of the series by not releasing ''Diablo 4'' on computer or home console. The situation was further stressed when ''[[Kotaku]]'' had claimed that inside sources told them that Blizzard had pulled a ''Diablo 4'' announcement at the last minute, which Blizzard refuted the next day.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Good |first1=Owen S. |title=Diablo fans call Diablo: Immortal a reskin of a free-to-play mobile game |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=2018-11-02 |url=https://www.polygon.com/mobile/2018/11/2/18057692/diablo-immortal-netease-mobile-game-crusaders-of-light-free-to-play |language=en-US |accessdate=2018-11-03 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last1=McWhertor |first1=Michael |title=Blizzard responds to Diablo: Immortal backlash |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=2018-11-03 |url=https://www.polygon.com/blizzcon/2018/11/3/18059222/diablo-immortal-blizzard-response-blizzcon |language=en-US |accessdate=2018-11-04 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Wade |first=Jessie |title=Update: Blizzard Says It 'Didn't Pull Any Announcements From Blizzcon' | work=[[IGN]] |date=2018-11-05 | url = https://www.ign.com/articles/2018/11/06/diablo-4-announcement-reportedly-pulled-from-blizzcon-2018 | accessdate=2018-11-05 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> |}
==References== {{reflist|30em}} *{{cite encyclopedia | title = Key Events in the History of Gaming & Violence | encyclopedia = Facts on File | volume = Issues and Controversies on File | pages = 58–62 | publisher = Facts on File Inc | year = 1997 | id =}} *{{cite web |last = Bali |first = Avinash |authorlink = |title = 10 Most Controversial Games Ever |work = Tech2.com India |publisher = Network 18 |date = 2006-11-10 |url = http://tech2.in.com/topstuff/games/10-most-controversial-games-ever-made/2769/0 |doi = |accessdate = 2008-07-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110815232412/http://tech2.in.com/topstuff/games/10-most-controversial-games-ever-made/2769/0 |archivedate = 2011-08-15 |df = }} *{{cite web | last = Bennett the Sage | first = | authorlink = | title = Top Ten Most Controversial Games | work = ScrewAttack | publisher = ScrewAttack Entertainment LLC. | date = 2008-06-24 | url = http://www.screwattack.com/user/minus273 | format = Flash | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-23 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120208022819/http://www.screwattack.com/user/minus273 | archivedate = 2012-02-08 | df = }} *{{cite web | last = supadupagame | first = | authorlink = | title = 11 most controversial games ever | work = VideoGamesBlogger | publisher = | date = 2006-11-11 | url = http://www.videogamesblogger.com/2006/11/11/11-most-controversial-games-ever.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-23}} *[http://www.gamesradar.com/slow-news-day-leads-to-portal-2-adoption-controversy/ Slow news day leads to Portal 2 adoption “controversy”]

How could the media possibly miss these button-pushing games?] by GamesRadar *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110616025659/http://www.gamesradar.com/ds/nintendo-ds/news/the-top-7-most-evil-games/a-20071217114714389015/g-20060308162345714070 The Top 7... Most Evil Games: See the most racist, hateful and tasteless titles you wouldn't touch with a 10 foot pole] by GamesRadar
